To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cattle in order to expand the business

loans.name: Lauben

texts.en: Mr. T. Lauben is a businessman with a studio with photographs and albums. He is using the loan for purchasing more photo frames and other studio items for his shop. He aspires to own a large studio and also hopes to start a video coverage business and create new opportunities. He has been operating the business for four years. He has four children, three schooling and one still at home.

loans.use: To purchase more photo frames and other studio items for his shop

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua D. is married and has three children, and her husband is a fisherman. She has no educational background. Efua sells smoked fish. She goes to the shore to buy fish and brings it home to process by smoking before selling it at the market which is at Kormantse near Cape Coast, which she has done since 2002.

Efua uses her income to take care of her children and educating them well. Efua will use the loan to purchase more fish to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua plans to further expand her fish-selling business.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Ermelinda

texts.en:
Ermelinda G. is 28 years old, married, and has two children. Her children are 8 and 9 years old and are both currently enrolled in school. She is originally from the city of Maputo. After she had her first child, Ermelinda and her husband decided to move to Boane where they could own a home rather than renting one in Maputo.

Ermelinda has been running her own business for the last 6 years. She originally learned her trade as an employee at the Mahafil social center. Her most profitable product is beer, where she can get a high profit margin.

This will be Ermelinda's second loan with Hluvuku. With this loan Ermelinda will try to grow her business and offer her customers better services. She hopes that with the success of her business she will be able to ensure her children's health and education.

loans.use: buying more merchandise to re-sell

loans.name: Rozik

texts.ru: Розик Зардаков проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст 52 года. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Розик более 4 лет занимается торговлей. Он имеет торговую точку на рынке, где торгует посудой. До этого он работал педагогом. Клиент просит кредит, для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Rozik Z. lives in the city Kulob. He is 52 years old, married and has 4 children. Rozik has been involved in sales for over 4 years. He has a retail store at the market, where he sells dishware. Previously, he worked as a teacher. Our client is requesting this loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah A. is a widow with two children. She has received no formal education. Hannah sells fish, which she buys from the fishermen and sends to her home to process before selling it at the market. She does her business at Kormantse near Cape Coast, which she has done since 1985.

Hannah uses her income to pay for her grandchildren’s education. Hannah will use the loan to buy more fish for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Hannah plans to further expand her fish-selling business.

loans.use: to buy more fish for sale

loans.name: Violah

texts.en:
Miss K. Violah is a business-lady operating a wholesale shop with items such as sugar, insecticides, shoe polish, cooking oil, soap, etc. She is using the loan to purchase more shop items such as sugar, sweets, soap, etc. for her shop. She has been operating the business for five years.

Violah has one child aged two years old. She aspires to own a larger grocery business and also hopes to get a banana plantation and create new opportunities for income generating.

loans.use: To purchase more items such as sugar, sweets, soap, etc for her shop

loans.name: Eldard

texts.en:
Mr. B. Eldard owns a boutique in Ibanda town. He sells used clothes in his boutique and sells other clothes in different markets. He is using the loan to purchase more clothes for his boutique.

He has been running this business for twelve years but before doing this business, he was a farmer. He has five children in secondary school. He works with his wife; sometimes she goes to the markets in case it is market day. Both have good customer care and they believe it this will enable them to get customers and maintain the stability of their business.

Mr. B. aspires to own a large scale boutique to sell a wide range of clothes in the same location so as to attract an awesome number of customers.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for his boutique

loans.name: Rahim

texts.ru: Зардов Рахим проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст 45 лет. Женат, имеет 9 детей. Рахим более 6 лет занимается животноводством, он покупает крупно рогатый скот откармливает и продает. Ему в этом такде помогают его дети. Клиент просит кредит, для покупки крупно рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Rahim Z. lives in the city of Kulob. He is 45 years old, married and has 9 children. Rahim has been involved in animal husbandry for over 6 years. He buys cattle, feeds it and resells it. His children also help him with the business. Our client is requesting this loan in order to purchase cattle.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Golibjon

texts.en:
B. Golibjon is 22 years old. He is married and has a young child. Golibjon is a noble worker dedicated to raising animals, primarily cattle, which he buys and sells in the commercial city markets. This work is very agreeable to him, because raising animals is what he enjoys most.

Golibjon requires a certain amount of money to increase the number of his cattle. His goal is to increase his product and thereby increase his household income in addition to being solvent in order to continue working at buying and selling animals.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing calves

loans.name: Cleshy

texts.en:
Mr. T. Cleshy is a courageous man, 40 years old. He is a married man with three children and expects to provide the best for them.

Mr. T. Cleshy has worked and lived in the area for over ten years. He owns a shop by the name of Twinomusuni, a family shop dealing in the selling of mattresses, pillows, blankets, towels, etc. He is using the loan to invest more in the business by buying mattresses, pillows, blankets, towels, etc. He is very happy and hopes his business will be self-sufficient. He is also a technical institute teacher and, meanwhile, his wife helps him to partly run the business. His future hope is to increase his inventory and create more employment.

loans.use: To invest in his businessby by buying more mattresses, pillows, blankets, towels, etc.

loans.name: Sharifa

texts.ru: Шарифа Мирзоева проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст 47 лет. Женат, имеет 10 детей. Шарифа более 6 лет занимается животноводством. Ее сыновья находятся в России, на заработках, муж занимается услугой такси. Шарифа покупает скот, откармливает и продает. Клиентка просит кредит, для покупки крупно рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Sharifa M. lives in the city of Kulob. She is 47 years old, married and has 10 children. Sharifa has been involved in animal husbandry for over 6 years. Her sons work in Russia, and her husband works as a taxi driver. Sharifa buys livestock, feeds it and resells it. Our client is requesting this loan in order to buy cattle.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Afivi

texts.fr:
E. afivi délali exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de pagnes, elle a associé à ce commerce la vente de bijoux, elle dispose d’une ancienneté de 5 ans dans ce commerce ce qui lui a  donné une parfaite maîtrise de ce commerce. Son stock de marchandises a  baissé, voulant rehausser son stock elle sollicite son premier crédit de WAGES pour acheter 30 pagnes « HI TARGET »
Et des bijoux.
Elle est mariée et a 02 enfants.
texts.en:
E. Afivi Délali earns her living selling "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth). At the same time, she sells costume jewelry. She has been in this line of work for 5 years already, which means that she has a mastery of this business. Her stock of merchandise is low, and, wishing to replenish it, she is asking for her first loan from WAGES to buy 30 Hi-Target-brand "pagnes" and some costume jewelry.

She is married and has 2 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of "pagnes"

loans.name: Syson

texts.en:
Mrs. N. Syson is a promising lady, 30 years old, and married with two children. Her husband is a very hardworking man with a welding shop in Bushenyi trading centre.

Mrs. N. Syson owns a hardware shop located in Kizinda trading centre and she has been performing her business for over three years. She is using the loan to invest in the business by purchasing more hardware. Her future plan is to increase her inventory and to create more employment.

Mrs. N. Syson also owns a banana plantation and sells bananas as a side income. Her future hope for the plantation is to increase its output.

loans.use: To invest in her business by purchasing more hardware

loans.name: Etonam

texts.fr:
Résidente du quartier d’adidogomé, cette femme  a débuté en 2006 le commerce des pagnes et tissus. Elle vend ses pagnes au marché local d’adidogomé et à domicile. Ses clientes deviennent de plus en plus nombreuses, elle voudrait mieux les satisfaire avec un plus grand stock, elle sollicite pour se faire un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 20 pièces de pagnes et  une douzaine de tissus.
Etant célibataire, le revenu qu’elle gagne de cette activité lui permet de subvenir à ses charges.
texts.en:
A resident of the Adidogomé neighborhood, this woman began selling "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth) and other fabrics in 2006. She sells her "pagnes" at the local market of Adidogomé and out of her home. Her customers are becoming more and more numerous, so she would like to better satisfy their needs by having a wide inventory. She is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 20 lengths of "pagne" and a dozen fabrics.

As a single woman, she is in this business to be able to support herself.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of "pagnes" and other fabrics

loans.name: Atsatou

texts.fr:
Cette femme est une résidente du quartier d’agbélépédo, un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de céréales, elle fait cette activité depuis 1995 et s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays, son stock de céréales a  baissé, voulant se réapprovisionner elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit  pour acheter 15 sacs de maïs et 10 sacs d’haricot.
Elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants qui font tous l’école primaire.
texts.en:
This woman is a resident of the Agbélépédo neighborhood, an outlying district of the city of Lomé. To earn a living, she sells cereals; she has been in this business since 1995. She buys her merchandise in the countryside. Her stock of cereals is low and in order to replenish it, she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 15 sacks of maize and 10 sacks of dried beans.

She is married and the mother of 2 children who are both in primary school.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of maize and dried beans

loans.name: Ena

texts.fr:
Cette femme s’est lancée dans le commerce de KAOLIN l’an dernier, elle exerce ce commerce dans le marché local d’adidogomé. Les femmes togolaises consomment le kaolin, étant la seule à exercer ce commerce dans son quartier, elle réalise de bonnes recettes tous les jours. Elle veut agrandir son stock et sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour acheter du Kaolin.
Elle  est mariée et mère de 03 enfants.
texts.en:
This woman began selling Kaolin (a kind of clay) last year. She does this in the local market of Adidogomé. Togolese women consume this clay, and since she is the only one to sell it in her neighborhood, she makes a good profit every day. She wants to expand her stock and is asking WAGES for a first loan to buy Kaolin.

She is married and the mother of 3 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing  KAOLIN (a type of clay)

loans.name: Maudah

texts.en:
Mrs. T. Maudah is a courageous lady of 43. She owns a retail shop located in Ishaka Trading Centre. She is married with six children. She is using the loan to invest more in her business, purchasing retail items such as sugar, soap, dry cells, etc and she expects to get big returns in terms of sales.

Her husband is a very hard-working businessman who owns a commercial building and rental houses in Ishaka trading centre. He also has a banana plantation and a farm with 8 cows where he gets bananas and milk for sale that earn him more income. Mrs. T. Maudah's future hope is to educate her children.

loans.use: purchasing retail items such as sugar, soap, dry cells, etc.

loans.name: Attaka

texts.fr: A. est une femme très dynamique, elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants, pour aider son mari dans les charges du foyer elle  a commencé le commerce de charbons de bois et de maïs. Elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays, ainsi elle arrive à réaliser de bonnes marges bénéficiaires sur ses recettes. Elle fait face en ce moment à une rupture de stock, voulant se réapprovisionner elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 7 sacs de charbons de bois et 5 sacs de maïs.
texts.en:
A. is a very dynamic woman, married and the mother of 2 children. To help her husband support the family, she began selling charcoal and maize. She buys her merchandise in the country, so she is able to make a good profit on her sales. She is presently experiencing a problem keeping her merchandise in stock, and wishing to replenish, she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 7 sacks of charcoal and 5 sacks of maize.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of charcoal and maize for resale

loans.name: Unidas Para Seguir 2 Group

texts.en:
Celeste (middle) is the coordinator of her group of five women named Unidas Para Seguir. She lives with her husband Salvador and 1-year-old son in their house just outside of Samaná, Dominican Republic, and this is her first loan with Esperanza.

Celeste currently sells various fruit juices from her home, and she says that many people come from all over her neighborhood to buy her juice. She sells juices varying from cantaloupe, to mango, to cherry, and various mixtures of other fruits. Celeste noticed that no one in the area was selling juices, and decided that she would be able to sell her juice easily due to the abundance of hot days in the Dominican Republic year-round. Now, business is brisk with people seeking a refreshing drink on any given hot day.

Celeste, with her supportive husband encouraging her in her business endeavor, is seeking to use the profits from selling juice in order to continue her studies at a university. She wants to someday be a teacher, and the money that her new business will bring in is going to help her afford the necessary classes. This in turn will allow her to help provide a better home for her child, and a better living situation for the family, in addition to her husband’s income.

For additional loans from Esperanza which still need funding, click the link at the bottom of this profile. You’ll see a list of other groups in the Dominican Republic, full of people just like Celeste, striving to help make a better life for themselves and their family.

http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&partner_id=44&status=fundRaising&sortBy=New+to+Old

loans.use: Additional fruit stock for her fruit juice business

loans.name: Eusebio Julio

texts.en:
Eusebio Julio M. is 47 years old, single, and resides in Boane. He is originally from Chibatu, where he lived until 1980. He then moved to Tete to continue his studies. He studied until the 9th grade and was forced to stop due to economic and social pressures. In 1982 he moved again from Tete to Maputo.

Eusebio provides for his 3 children between the ages of 12 and 17. He is employed by Delta Force where he has worked for the past 9 years. This will be Eusebio's third loan with Hluvuku and he intends to use it to make improvements to his home.

loans.use: Construction Materials

loans.name: Julio

texts.en:
Julio A. is currently in the business of selling beer at home and is requesting a loan to open up a bar. Julio is 42 years old and is married to a husband who is a security guard. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: open up a bar

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en: Ms. Aisha Z. has a restaurant located at Mbarara Bus Park. She has two children and they are both in school. She has been operating the business for over seven years. She is using the loan to increase  the products in the restaurant like adding more drinks, different foods on the menu, etc. She intends to work hard and increase her stock and make her business a success. Her future hope is to open up another small hotel.

loans.use: adding more drinks, different foods on the menu, etc.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba N. sells fish. She goes to the shore to buy fresh fish and then smokes it before selling it at the market at Kormatse near Cape Coast which she has been doing since 2002. Aba has no educational background. She is married and has four children; her husband is a fisherman

She is responsible for paying for her children’s education. Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy more fish to sell at the market. She hopes to use the profits she gains to further expand her business.

loans.use: increase her capital to buy more fish to sell at the market

loans.name: Unidas Para Seguir 3 Group

texts.en:
Dolores D. L. R. (middle) is the coordinator of her group of five women named Unidas Para Seguir.  In a house just outsiD. of Samaná, Dominican Republic, Dolores lives with her three children, ages 19, 16, and 14.  Dolores is currently on her first loan, making charcoal, which she sells to others in her neighborhood.  

While this may be her first loan with Esperanza, Dolores has been selling charcoal now for several years.  Many people in the neighborhood depend on this charcoal for cooking and other uses.  She makes her charcoal in a clearing in the trees which line one of the streets in the neighborhood.

Dolores took out the loan in the hopes that it would help her business continue to grow.  She sees this as a great opportunity to expand her production, and is seeking to support her children’s career goals with the additional funds.  Two of her children want to be a doctor and a lawyer, and Dolores would love to be able to support them long enough for them to study in a nearby university.  This loan has become an opportunity to invest in her children’s education and career aspirations.

loans.use: buying new equipment, sacks, and other goods to expand her charcoal production

loans.name: Deya

texts.en:
Deya L. is currently in the business of selling tea at Konyokonyo market and is requesting a loan to purchase more sugar to make tea to sell. Deya is 26 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land for setting up a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more sugar to make tea to sell

loans.name: Gloria Carlos

texts.en:
Gloria Carlos C. is 42 years old, married, and the mother of 4 children. She currently resides in Boane, but was born in Maputo. She went to school until she became pregnant for the first time and was forced to drop out to attend to her children. Her children are aged 7, 16, 19, and 23; all are in school except the oldest, who now works.

Gloria has her own retail operation, specializing in the sale of children's clothing. This will be her first loan with Hluvuku. She intends on using the loan to diversify her product line. Over time she hopes to continue to further grow her operation and become more profitable

loans.use: buy more inventory for her business

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase beans and maize flour to sell. Poni is 27 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a sewing machine.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase beans and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Naana

texts.en:
Naana A. sells gari (a fried cassava dish); she buys cassava and then mills it and fries it to get her gari. She then packages it in sacks before sending it for sale at the market at Kormantse near Cape Coast. Naana has received junior high school education. She is married and has five children. Her husband is a fisherman. 

Naana has been selling gari since 2003. She is responsible for feeding her family and also for paying her children’s school fees. Her loan will be used to increase her capital in order to buy more cassava to process and sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to support her husband in educating their children.

loans.use: To increase her capital in order to buy more cassava to process and sell

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en: Mr. M. Godfrey has a retail or grocery shop at Mbarara old taxi park. He is using the loan to increase the stock in his shop by buying retail items such as cooking oil, shoe polish, dry cells, soap, salt, maize flour, sandals, etc. He intends to increase his stock and hopes to open up another branch for his grocery. He has been operating the business for over six years. He has six children; four of them are in school.

loans.use: To increase his stock

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas B. is married and has two dependants. She has received schooling through junior high school. Dorcas sells provisions and gari, which she gets from processed cassava. She does this business at Kormantse near Cape Coast. She has been doing this since 1999. Her husband is a commercial driver. Dorcas uses her income to feed her family. Dorcas will use the loan to buy provisions and to purchase more cassava to process into gari for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Dorcas plans to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To buy provisions and purchase more cassava

loans.name: Bitorina

texts.en:
Bitorina J. is currently in the business of selling bread and paste and is requesting a loan to open a bakery. Bitorina is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a bakery

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Mr. M. Moses is a businessman operating a restaurant called New Lucky Hotel. He serves foods like millet, meat, beans, rice and groundnuts. He is using the loan to purchase more quantities and varieties of food to increase sales. He has been operating the business for seven years. He has two children aged between two and six years respectively; one is in primary one while the young one is still at home. He aspires to own a large hotel and hopes to increase the variety of foods served.

loans.use: To purchase more food for his restaurant

loans.name: Unidas Para Seguir Group

texts.en:
Melida M. (far right) is one member of the group Unidas para Seguir.  She lives with her three children and her husband a few kilometers outsiD. of Samaná, Dominican Republic.  Currently she works as the neighborhood veterinarian, going from house to house helping in any way she can with animals.  She is on her eighth loan with Esperanza, and currently sells and administers vaccines, vitamins and antibiotics in her neighborhood.  She loves working with the animals, and after seeing a need for veterinary care, she took it upon herself to begin work in the area.  Many people she knows have pigs, so a majority of her work is with those animals, though she does do some work with cats, dogs and other animals as well.

Melida has several goals for the future, as her business continues to grow.  Her additional income, along with the income her husband brings in fishing, will allow her to fix up her house – and to add an additional room or two as money allows.  On top of this, Melida dreams of someday owning a house with enough property outsiD. where she can raise cows.  She got a big smile on her face when talking about someday being able to raise cows of her own, rather than just tending to those owned by others.  For now, this is only a desire for Melida, as she uses much of her income just to help pay for food for the family.  Her income, combined with her husbands, is not yet sufficient to buy both food and pursue her other goals.  Melida is striving to grow her business day by day, and is very thankful for any help you can proviD.!

loans.use: To buy antibiotics, vitamins, vaccines and other goods for her veterinary practice

loans.name: Humid

texts.en: Humid I. sells car parts like tires and food supplies like rice and groundnuts at Salt Pond near Cape Coast. Humid has received education through senior high school. He is married and has two dependants. His wife is a trader. Humid has been selling car parts and food supplies like rice and groundnuts since 1999. He is responsible for feeding his family and paying utility bills and school fees. His loan will be used to increase his capital to buy more car parts and food supplies for sale at the market. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to care his family.

loans.use: To buy more car parts and food supplies

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua O. sells fish. She buys fresh fish from the shore and sends it home for processing through smoking before she sells it at the market, which is at Kormantse near Cape Coast. Efua has received no formal education. She is married and has two children; her husband is a fisherman. She has been doing this business since 1989. She is responsible for feeding her children and paying bills. Her loan will be used to purchase more fish to process for sale at the market. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more fish

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Ms A. Diana has a retail shop (grocery) located at Kakyeka. She has been operating the business for four years. She has one child not yet in school. She is requesting a loan to increase the stock in her shop by purchasing items like sugar, toilet paper, soap, bread etc. She intends to increase her stock and hopes to enlarge her shop into a big grocery and retail shop.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her shop

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort E. sells bread. She uses flour, sugar, margarine, and other ingredients to prepare it. She does this business at Kormantse near Cape Coast. Comfort has received education through the primary school level.  She is married and has four children. Her husband is a fisherman. Comfort has been selling bread since 2005. She is responsible for feeding her family and paying her children’s school fees. Her loan will be used to purchase more flour, margarine, sugar and so on, to bake more bread for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to take care of her children.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for bread

loans.name: Kobena

texts.en: Kobena E. is married and has four children. He has no educational background. Kobena sells gari, which he gets from processed cassava at Kormantse near Cape Coast. He has done this since 1990. His wife is a trader. Kobena uses his income to feed his family and pay his children’s school fees. Kobena will use the loan to increase his capital to buy more cassava to process for sale. With the new profits from his expanded business, Kobena plans to save towards building a new house.

loans.use: To buy more cassava to process for sale.

loans.name: Naana

texts.en:
Naana S. sells gari (a fried cassava dish) which she gets by processing cassava, which she does at Kormantse near Cape Coast. She has received no formal education. She is married and has four dependents. Her husband is a trader.

Naana has sold gari since 1997 and her loan will be used to buy more cassava to process into gari for sale. She is responsible for catering for her family. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To buy to more cassava to process into gari and sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama Y. is married and has five children. She has no educational background. Her husband is a trader.

Ama cooks and sells beans and gari (a fried cassava dish) at Kormantse near Cape Coast, which she has done since 1999. She uses her income to feed her family and also to pay her children’s school fees. She will use the loan to increase the capital of her business, enabling her to purchase more fresh beans to be cooked and sold. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh beans to be cooked and sold

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama G. is married and has three children. She has no educational background. Her husband is a steel burner.

Ama cooks rice and sells it with variety of sauces at Kormantse near Cape Coast, which she has been doing since 1998. She uses her income to pay for feeding her family and also for paying her children’s school fees.

Ama will use the loan to purchase rice and other ingredients and also to buy utensils to add to what she uses to cook the rice. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans to pay her children’s school fees.

At the time this picture was taken, she had finished selling the food and was packing up her cooking bowls.

loans.use: To buy rice and ingredients and more utensils

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi N. is married to a commercial driver and has three children. She has received no formal education. Since 1999 Esi has sold provisions such as milk, Milo, sugar, soap and rice, at Kormantse, near Cape Coast. She uses her income to feed her family and pay her children’s school fees. Esi will use her loan to purchase more groceries to fill her grocery store. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to take care of her children.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort Q. is married to a security guard and has one child. She has received schooling through junior high school. Since 1989 Comfort has sold fish and kenkey (a sourdough dumpling) at Kormantse, near Cape Coast. She uses her income to feed her family and pay her utility bills. Comfort will use her loan to increase her capital to buy corn to prepare her kenkey and fried fish. With the new profits from her expanded business, Comfort plans to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To buy corn to prepare kenkey

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice F. is married and has three children. She has received schooling through junior high school. Since 1999 Alice has sold groceries and gari, a flour that she prepares herself by processing milled cassava. Her business is based at Kormantse, near Cape Coast. Alice uses her income for feeding her family and paying the utility bills. She will use her loan to purchase more groceries for her store and cassava for processing into gari. With the new profits from her expanded business, Alice plans to take care of her children.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for her store and cassava for processing into gari

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua T. sells soft drinks and other groceries at Kormantse near Cape Coast. She has received education through to the junior high school level. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Efua has been selling soft drinks and other groceries since 2000. She is responsible for feeding her family. Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy more of the soft drinks she sells and also groceries such as milk, Milo (a milk beverage), rice, sugar, soap and so on to fill her shop. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards building a house for the family.

loans.use: To buy more of the soft drinks and groceries she sells

loans.name: Alisati's Group

texts.en:
N. Alisati is the leader of Walusubi group in Lugazi. She is a hard-working and friendly lady who has had a business selling produce for 4 years (since 2005) in Walusubi, Namawojjolo. As a result, she has been able to make a weekly profit of 80,000/= and 320,000/= monthly. She buys produce like cassava, matooke (green bananas), maize and beans from the villages and sells as a retailer.

N. Alisati has a dream of being able to purchase the produce from the farmers herself instead of buying through middlemen to reduce the cost of transactions. She also hopes to have an educated family--for all her children to attend university and have better jobs. Alisati is a married lady with 4 children, aged 17 – 3, and she cares for 6 dependents. She needs a loan to be able to purchase more produce.

loans.use: Buying more produce for sale

loans.name: Ines

texts.es: Inés es una mujer muy trabajadora que trata siempre de que sus seres queridos cuenten con lo necesario para su desarrollo, en especial sus hijos, quienes son su mayor tesoro y junto a ellos vive en la casa de su madre. El apoyo de una amiga fue determinante para el desarrollo de su actividad como comerciante, ya que trabaja asociada junto a ella en un puesto dentro del mercado de su distrito. Donde desde hace 3 años a partir de las 7 de la mañana hasta las 3 de la tarde vende todo tipo de productos y artículos, pero en especial comestibles. En todo este tiempo ella y su socia no dejan de esforzarse al máximo, pues su ambición es contar con puestos independientes donde cada una maneje sus propias inversiones y capital. Pero mientras no tengan esa posibilidad tratan de disfrutar el tiempo que tiene juntas para aunar esfuerzos y apoyarse en lo que requieran. Además la concurrencia es creciente y cada vez es mayor, sobre todo los días feriados cuando la demanda es mayor. Este es su crédito número 24 con Microfinanzas PRISMA y junto a sus compañeras de banco comunal trabajan con mucho compromiso y responsabilidad en sus pagos, ya que han pasado por momentos difíciles debido a la irresponsabilidad de algunas personas que abandonaron el grupo. Los 1500 soles que solicita los usará en la compra la mercadería que requiere para abastecer la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Ines is a hard-working woman who always tries to give her loved ones what they needed, especially to her children who are her greatest treasure. She lives with them in her mothers’ house. The support of a friend was decisive for the development of her business as a trader. She works associated with her in a booth at the market district.

She sells all kinds of products, especially food from 7 Am until 3 Pm and has been doing it for the last 3 years. Throughout this time she and her partner continue to try their best, because her ambition is to have separate booths where each one can manage their own investments and capital. But while this opportunity arrives they try to enjoy the time together to combine efforts and support each other. The affluence of customers is growing and increasing, especially on holidays when the demand is the greatest. This is her 24th loan with PRISMA and, along with her fellow community bank members, is working with a lot of commitment and responsibility in the payments because they have gone through difficult times due to the irresponsibility of some people who left the group. The loan requested will be invested in the purchase of goods to meet the needs of her customers. .

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing goods for grocery

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina D. C. is 34 year old wife and the mother of three children. She lives in a urban area of Pasay. Her children are all of school age; one is in elementary school and two are in high school. Her husband is also her partner in running their business.

Her business, cooking pork skin cracklings, has been financing her family’s needs for eight years. She cooks, packs, and delivers the product by herself to client's retail stores. She sells the crackling wholesale and her husband peddles around communities and sells them retail. 

This is Cristina's 8th loan from the Center for Community Transformation (CCT). Her most recent loan was for PHP9,000. The business now earns PHP19,320 per month and it helps to send her children to school. She has never missed a loan payment.

Cristina wishes to provide better living conditions for her children and give them good opportunities in life. Her business is greatly improving and expanding and it has contributed so much to her children’s future.

CCT is a is family-oriented and Bible-centered Filipino development organization that provides and creates equal business opportunities for small-scale Filipino entrepreneurs through loans and social interventions.

loans.use: Additional capital for their business

loans.name: Cristo Vive, Group 2

texts.en:
Blazina S. is the group leader for the Cristo Vive loan group. She is unmarried but lives with the father of her four children, ages five, seven, nine, and eleven.

Blazina makes her living selling clothes and shoes out of a rented stall, and has done so for the past year. With this loan, she plans to buy a more diverse, higher quality stock of goods to expand her business, with hopes to eventually open her own small shop.

Blazina has taken out and repaid four loans in the past, and says that being an Esperanza associate has improved her outlook on life, both economically and otherwise.

Blazina appreciates any help you can offer her and the other women in her group!

loans.use: Clothing to sell

loans.name: Necitas

texts.en:
The mother of four children, two of whom are twins, Necitas C. helps with the family expenses by running a charcoal business. She lives in Pasay City with her children and her husband, who is a public tricycle operator in their community.

She started her charcoal business a year and a half ago when the educational expenses for their four children became too much for their tricycle operation to handle. The charcoal business earns PHP4,500 per month, just enough to barely carry the family through each day.

Necitas and her husband want to improve their living situation by starting another business. To get more funding for the charcoal-making business, Necitas plan to deliver larger volumes of charcoal to more public wet markets (open-air food markets) and flea markets in Pasay.

Necitas has never missed a savings or loan payment. Her previous loan was for PHP18,000. She is now borrowing her fourth loan from the Center for Community Transformation (CCT).

CCT is a Filipino family-oriented and Bible-centered development organization that provides and creates equal business opportunities for small-scale Filipino entrepreneurs through loans and social interventions.

loans.use: Additional capital for her charcoal business

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose D. S. I. is 60 years old, married, and the father of 2 children, aged 3 months and 6 years old. He also supports three other people that he sends remittance payments to. He is originally from Chibauto, located in the province of Gaza, but currently resides in Boane. For the last 13 years he has worked 10 hours a day as a painting instructor in an orphanage. Before working at the orphanage, he worked Mozambique Cement.

This will be Jose's third loan with Hluvuku. The previous loans he took out were for MT 15,000 and MT 25,000. Both loans were repaid successfully. He intends to use this loan to make necessary improvements to his home.

loans.use: Construction Materials

loans.name: Jessica

texts.es: Jessica es una mujer emprendedora y optimista, a pesar de estar separada de su pareja trata de brindar lo necesario a su hijo, con quien vive en la casa de su madre. Tuvo la oportunidad de adquirir un puesto dentro del mercado de su localidad, la cual no dejó pasar y desde hace 7 años viene vendiendo diversidad de productos. Cuando recién comenzó sólo contaba con algunos artículos, mas ahora tiene gran variedad, sobre todo de comestibles. Para atender su puesto tienen que levantarse muy temprano para salir rumbo al mercado donde trabaja desde las  6 de la mañana hasta las 5 de la tarde, ya que en ese lapos de tiempo la demanda es mayor por la cantidad de personas que la visitan y en algunas oportunidades ha tenido que solicitar ayuda para atender a todos sus clientes. Para un futuro cercano, Jessica desea incrementar su mercadería e instalar un puesto adicional en el mercado donde contrataría a otras personas para que la ayuden con la atención. Los 24 préstamos que ha tenido con Microfinanzas PRISMA fueron gracias a la conformación de su banco comunal, donde cada miembro trata de trabajar activamente y lo más resaltante es que a pesar de los problemas que han atravesado siguen con el mismo ánimo de superación. Los 1500 soles que solicita serán destinados al incremento de sus productos para satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Jessica is an enterprising and optimistic woman. In spite of being separated from her partner she tries to provide the necessities for her son with whom she lives in the house of her mother. She had the opportunity to acquire a stand in the market of her town which she could not pass up and for seven years she has been selling a variety of products. When she just started out she only had a few articles, and now has a large variety, above all food. In order to attend her stand she must rise very early to set out for the market where she works from 6am until 5pm since during this time period the demand is better for the amount of people that visit and in some cases she has had to ask for help in order to attend to all of her customers.

For the near future Jessica wants to increase her merchandise and install an additional stand in the market where she will hire other people to help her with her business. The 24 loans she has had with Microfinanzas PRISMA were thanks to the structure of her communal bank where every member tries to work actively and the most outstanding thing is that in spite of the problems blocking them, they continue with the same cheer and determination.

The 1500 PEN that she asks for is to increase her products in order to satisfy the demand of her customers.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her merchandise

loans.name: Esther's Group

texts.en:
N. Esther is the leader of Nabuti group in Mukono. She is a hard-working business-lady and has been a market vendor for 10 years dealing in Irish potatoes, sweet potatoes, yams, cassava, etc. in Kame Valley market in Mukono. She is a married lady with 3 children aged 10, 7 and 1 and she cares for 7 dependents.

Esther says that it’s because of her quality produce that customers keep coming to her for goods and this enables her to make 300,000/= per week. She needs a loan to help purchase more stock of goods for sale. In the photo is also the Credit Officer for the group, Winnie.

loans.use: Purchasing more stock for her business

loans.name: Leonilde

texts.en:
Leonilde D. G., 54, is originally from Chidenguela, but currently resides in Boane. She is divorced and is the mother of three children aged 25, 29, and 31. She is also responsible for two nephews who live with her.

Leonilde runs a small store that sells various products. She has one employee. Her best selling products are fish and crackers. With this loan she hopes to be able to introduce new products to her store. This will be Leonilde's first loan with Hluvuku. She is interested in taking out further loans in the future to help remodel her home.

loans.use: adding to her inventory

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: María es una mujer de 63 años, el bienestar de sus seres queridos es su prioridad, por lo que ha trabajado muy arduamente durante todos estos años dejando a sus hijos una casa propia donde habitar cómodamente. Desde muy joven trabajó en múltiples actividades, pero los años la obligaron a dejar de realizar labores pesadas que perjudicaban su salud, pero no le quitaron las ganas de progresar. Con los ahorros que tenía, junto a su esposo, instaló una tienda en su vivienda, la cual viene funcionando desde hace 20 años a partir de las 6 de la mañana hasta la media noche. Durante este tiempo, María atiende muy alegremente a todos sus clientes, sus hijos la ayudan los fines de semana para la venta de bebidas y ella espera que siga teniendo la clientela que hasta hoy posee producto de la atención de calidad que siempre trata de brindar. Sin embargo, no deja de tener aspiraciones en su vida y se ha proyectado a mejorar su negocio con el incremento de mayor variedad de productos y la implementación de un nuevo espacio para ofrecer nueva mercadería. Con Microfinanzas PRISMA ya tiene 13 préstamos con los que ha ido consolidando su compromiso con su banco comunal, donde colabora con las diversas actividades a fin de mejorar cada vez más la organización de su grupo. Con los 1000 soles que solicita incrementará su capital de trabajo para adquirir productos de mejor calidad y variedad de marcas.
texts.en:
María is a woman of 63 years of age. The well-being of her loved ones is her priority, thus she has worked very hard all these years such that her children now live comfortably in the house the family owns. Since she was very young María has worked several jobs; eventually her age kept her from doing heavy labor that harmed her health, but didn't take away her desire to make progress. With her and her husband's savings she set up a store in the house, which has been operating for 20 years. It is open from 6:00 a.m. to midnight. During this time, María happily attends to her customers. Her children help her on the weekends, selling beverages. María hopes to keep her customers, who are a result of the good customer service she always tries to provide. Nevertheless, she has aspirations of her own and plans to improve her business with a greater variety of products and more space in which to sell new merchandise. She has already had 13 loans with Microfinanzas PRISMA, which have strengthened her commitment to her community bank, where she collaborates with the diverse membership to continuously improve the group's organization. With the 1,000 PEN loan she is requesting, she will increase her working capital to acquire products of higher quality and greater brand variety.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing merchandise

loans.name: Micerina

texts.es: Micerina es una mujer de  50 años, se caracteriza por su gran sentido del humor y la alegría que siempre mantiene, lo cual es gracias a su familia quienes son el motor de su trabajo. La preparación de diversos platillos y bocaditos se ha convertido en la mejor actividad económica que realiza, ya que los pedidos que tiene son continuos, lo cual refleja la habilidad que tiene para la cocina. Esta actividad la realiza hace 6 años en su casa, donde prepara los diversos pedidos para llevarlos a los eventos sociales donde la contratan, los cuales durante las fechas festivas son mayores, tratando de aprovecharlos aunque le tome noches sin dormir, pues sus ganancias son muy buenas. Para brindar mejor atención a sus clientes participa en diversos talleres de preparación de alimentos y siempre aprende nuevas formas de sazón y presentación de los platos. De esta manera, Micerina trata de aprender cada día más, pues su deseo es ampliar sus redes sociales para incrementar sus pedidos y darse a conocer dentro de su distrito. Asimismo, desea instalar una tienda en su casa donde pueda tener un negocio adicional que la ayude a mantener sus ingresos estables. Con Microfinanzas PRISMA ya tiene 24 créditos a través de su banco comunal, el cual formó hace más de 10 años junto a un grupo de amigas con quienes viene trabajando armoniosamente. Con los 3200 soles que solicita comprará los comestibles e ingredientes que requiere para la preparación de sus comidas y la instalación de su tienda.
texts.en:
Micerina is a 50-year-old woman known for her great sense of humor and for her upbeat personality, which are both thanks to her family who is the motivation for her work. The preparation of different dishes and sandwiches has become her largest source of income since the orders that she has are continuous, which reflects her skill in the kitchen. She has been doing this for 6 years from her home, where she prepares the different orders to take them to the social events where she has been hired and which occur more often during the holidays. She tries to take advantage of them even if she goes without sleep some nights since her earnings are very high. In order to attract more attention from clients, she participates in different food preparation workshops and always learns new ways to season and present the dishes. In this way, Micerina tries to learn a little more each day, since her wish is to expand her social networks in order to increase her orders and make herself known throughout her district. Likewise, she wants to set up a store in her home where she can have an additional business that will help her maintain a stable income. With PRISMA Microloans, she already has 24 loans through her communal bank, which she formed more than 10 years ago with a group of friends with whom she continues to work well. With the 3200 soles that she is requesting, she will buy groceries and ingredients that she needs to prepare foods and to set up her shop.

Translated from Spanish by Tara Binetti, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy groceries for food preparation and for setting up her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing film and wood for greenhouse construction

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah A. is thirty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, both girls. Both are currently in senior high and junior high schools. She lives with her husband and daughters in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Dwenase in the Western Region. Dwenase is a suburb of Sefwi-Wiawso, the district capital.

Hannah is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice and stew. She sells on a table top at the lorry station in the afternoons. She wants a loan to buy bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk. Hannah buys her goods from nearby communities. She has been in business for six years. She aspires to expand her business and give her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Miguel

texts.es: Miguel es una persona muy empeñosa y dedicada a su familia, quien está muy contenta por contar con un padre y esposo tan responsable que les brindó una casa propia y un hogar agradable donde habitar. Desde que era joven trabajó en múltiples obras de construcción como albañil y la experiencia que adquirió le dio la posibilidad de acceder a un trabajo bajo el orden público (del estado) donde  se ocupa desde las 9 de la mañana hasta las 4 de la tarde, tiempo que labora con mucho agrado pues desempeñarse en la labor que tanto le gusta lo motiva. Sin embargo, desea tener un negocio propio donde pueda obtener ingresos adicionales, realizando construcciones independientes. Este es su primer crédito con Microfinanzas PRISMA y muchas ganas de continuar siendo parte de su banco comunal por mucho tiempo. Los 3000 soles que solicita los invertirá en la compra de materiales de construcción para realizar sus trabajos independientes como albañil.
texts.en:
Miguel is very dedicated and devoted to his family. They are very happy to count on a responsible father and husband who provided them with their own house and a nice home where they live. Since he was young, he worked on many construction sites as a bricklayer and the experience he gained gave him the possibility to work for the state. He works from 9 in the morning to 4 in the afternoon, time which he labors with much enjoyment, as working in a field that he likes so much motivates him. Nevertheless, he wants to have his own business where he can obtain an additional income, working on independent construction projects. This is his first loan with Microfinanzas PROSMA, and he is eager to continue being a part of this community bank for a long time. The $1000 (3000 PEN) loan which he asks for will be invested in the purchase of construction materials in order to perform independent work as a bricklayer.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Trad, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials and tools

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary N. is forty-seven years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, two sons and two daughters. All are currently in senior high and junior high schools. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a commercial town in the Western region called Dwenase, a suburb of Sefwi-Wiawso. She is a hard-working woman.

Mary runs a provisions store. She sells groceries such as Milo (cocoa powder), sugar, rice, candies, bread, etc. in a store on the street. She has been in business for over twenty years now and wants a loan to buy more provisions to expand her business. She is hopeful to improve her standard of living and give her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy provisions to sell

loans.name: Hasifa's Group

texts.en:
N. Hasifa is the leader of Balikudembe group in Buwola. She is a polite woman and a married mother of 5 children aged 14-2 years, of whom 4 are in primary school. She is a business-lady selling "nakati" (green vegetables) that she grows in her gardens; she also keeps sheep and goats for meat and wants to expand her farm.

Her customers for the green vegetables are located all over Lugazi and she is lucky that her customers come to her for the purchases, hence allowing her to save on transport. She is able to make weekly profits of 30,000/= per week (minus the sale of animals). Hasifa needs a loan to top up with her current savings and buy another piece of land to expand her farming.

loans.use: Buying a plot of land to expand her farming

loans.name: Marcia

texts.en:
Marcia R. M. is 37 years old. She is originally from Maputo and is the mother of two children aged 12 and 18. She was left by her boyfriend, who went to find work in South Africa, so she now lives with and sustains her two children. 

Marcia works selling products from a stand in Boane. Her best selling products are peanuts and beans. She intends on using this loan to increase her stand's inventory and to offer new products. In the future she plans on requesting further loans to continue to grow her business.

loans.use: To increase her stand's inventory and to offer new products

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles A., a 46-year-old married father of three sons and two daughters who are all currently in school – senior high, junior high and primary schools -  lives with his family in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Dwenase in the Western Region. His wife is a trader, as is Charles, who sells plantain. He buys his goods from nearby communities at affordable prices and sells at the market square in his community, supplying both food vendors and retailers. He also treks to other markets to sell on their market days. Charles has been in business for three years and is requesting a loan to buy goods in bulk. He aspires to expand his business and sponsor his children in school as far as they wish to study.

loans.use: To buy plantain.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es: Gloria tiene 30 años, vive con su esposo y su hijo de 17 años en la casa de sus padres. Desde hace 3 años se dedica a vender productos alimenticios como papa, queso, olluco y otros típicos de su región, ella los lleva a otras ciudades, viajando 3 veces al mes para realizar este trabajo. Su esposo la ayuda a transportar los paquetes de mercadería hasta la agencia de viajes, una vez que llega a su destino almacena su mercadería en la casa de una amiga mientras la va comercializando. Con esta forma de trabajo Gloria ha visto muy buenas ganancias que le han permitido ser fuente sustentadora de su hogar. Esto la anima a planificar su futuro en base a este negocio, estableciéndose en un local comercial en una zona céntrica de su ciudad. Es la tercera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, así como la experiencia de trabajar en un banco comunal, donde se siente muy contenta de pertenecer a ese grupo que le ha enseñado el  valor de la solidaridad y la responsabilidad. El dinero que está solicitando será destinado a incrementar su capital de trabajo para que siga con las ventas que ha planificado.
texts.en:
Gloria is 30 years old and lives with her husband and 17-year-old son in her parents’ home.
She has sold food like potatoes, cheese, olluco and other local produce for three years. She travels to other cities three times a month to sell her food. Her husband helps her transport her merchandise to the travel agency. Once she reaches her destination, she stores her produce in a friend’s house while she goes about selling it. This business has been profitable for Gloria and has allowed her to provide for her household, encouraging her to build a future by establishing a commercial location in the city centre.
This is the third time she has received a loan through MFP and worked with a communal bank. She is very happy to belong to this group that has taught her the value of solidarity and responsibility. The money she is requesting will be used as working capital to continue on with her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace O. is forty-four years old. She is married and has given birth to four children: two sons and two daughters. All are currently in the junior high and the primary schools. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Dwenase, a suburb of Sefwi-Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana.

Grace is a trader, selling printed textiles goods – java, fancy, wax, etc. She hawks (goes door-to-door) to sell and also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. Grace has been in business for six years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk. She desires to expand her business and give her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy textiles in bulk

loans.name: Jorge

texts.es: Jorge tiene 40 años, vive con su esposa y sus 3 hijos de 18,14 y 12 años en su casa propia. Se dedica a la crianza de ganado vacuno en el establo que implementó en su misma casa; todos los días su esposa y sus hijos lo apoyan en el cuidado de sus animales en cuanto a la limpieza del establo y la alimentación. Después de varios meses de crianza Jorge y su familia van a la feria ganadera de su localidad para vender sus toros, obteniendo un buen precio por ellos. Adicionalmente, vende la leche que extrae de sus vacas y cultiva algunas chacras de papa y maíz. Para un futuro cercano, Jorge desea un establo más grande y mejorarlo en cuanto a su infraestructura. Esta es la tercera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP y él es uno de los miembros de su banco comunal más comprometido y que participa activamente por el bienestar de su grupo. El dinero que está solicitando será invertido en la compra de una vaca de una buena raza.
texts.en:
Jorge is 40 years old and lives with his wife and 3 children (ages 18, 14, and 12) in a house that they own. He tends to the cattle housed inside the barn built next door. Every day, his wife and children assist him with the care of the animals by feeding them and cleaning the stalls. Once the calves are weaned after several months of nursing, Jorge and his family go to the local livestock fair to sell the bulls, getting a good price for them. In addition, he sells the milk from his cows, as well as the potatoes and corn grown on his farm. In the near future, Jorge would like to build a larger barn and make overall improvements around his farm.

This is his third loan with MFP. Jorge is one of the more committed members of his communal bank and actively looks after the best interests of his group. The money he is requesting will be used to purchase a cow of good breed.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a cow

loans.name: Magdalena Lwamulungi's Group

texts.en:
Magdalena is the leader of a five-person group. She is 46 years old, married, and has seven children  who are between 12 and 27 years of age. Four of her children go to school. 

Magdalena lives in a rented four-room house where she is staying with two people. Magdalena doesn't take care of any additional family members. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day. She lives and works in a semi-urban area that is in the outskirts of Kampala. 

Magdalena operates a retail shop in Nalukolongo. She uses public transport to and from Kampala city where she shops twice a week. She sells to an average of 20 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Her major monthly expenses include medication, rent for both accommodation and business, and feeding the family. She has been in this business for the last 20 years. Magdalena has been with MCDT for over five years and this is her 20th loan, all working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise for her shop. Magdalena aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent business premise and home. 

.

loans.use: To buy merhandise for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Finishing touches to housing interior

loans.name: Ronald

texts.es: Ronald tiene 28 años, vive con sus padres en la casa de sus abuelos. Desde hace un año y medio se dedica a brindar el servicio de llamadas telefónicas de forma ambulatoria en las puertas de la universidad de su ciudad. Cada día trabaja desde temprano por la mañana y durante la tarde, ya que por la noche estudia en la universidad. De esta manera se sostiene económicamente y puede paga sus gastos educativos. Además, también se dedica al alquiler de equipos de sonidos para eventos sociales, hasta el momento este negocio le está resultando rentable, por lo que está planeando para el futuro establecerse en un local donde también tenga un centro de llamadas. Esta es la tercera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, Ronald decidió renovar su compromiso de trabajo con su banco comunal porque ha logrado entablar una bella amistad con cada uno de sus integrantes. El dinero que está solicitando será destinado a la compra de más teléfonos celulares que son sus herramientas básicas para su trabajo.
texts.en:
Ronald is 28 years old, and lives with his parents in his grandparent's house. For a year and a half he has worked providing a mobile phonecall service, at the gates of the university in his city. Each day he works early in the morning and during the afternoon, because at night he studies at university. In this way he sustains himself economically and can pay his education expenses. As well as this, he also rents sound equipment for social events, which has resulted in a profitable business. Because of which, in the future he is planning to establish it in an area where he can also have a telephone call centre. This is the third time he has had a loan with MFP. Ronald decided to renew his work commitment with his communal bank because he has been able to strike up a lovely friendship with each one of the members. The money he is seeking will be destined for the purchase of more cell phones which are the basic tools of his work.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy mobile phones

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rufino

texts.es: Rufino tiene 50 años, vive con su hijo de 25 años y también está al cuidado de su madre. Desde hace 4 años se dedica a la venta de animales menores (cuyes) en las principales ferias ganaderas de su localidad. Sus ventas las realiza todos los fines de semana y los demás días, con ayuda de su madre, se dedica al cuidado y alimentación de sus cuyes en la granja que ha implementado en su casa. Debido al buen cuidado que brinda a sus animales ha tenido buenas ventas porque sus cuyes tienen buen tamaño y peso. Para un futuro cercano, Rufino quiere ampliar su granja y mejorar la raza de sus animales para que siga adelante con sus ventas. Esta es la tercera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, su compromiso durante estos años (2) de trabajo en su banco comunal es reconocido por los demás integrantes y su deseo es seguir aportando lo mejor para el bienestar de su grupo. El dinero que está solicitando será destinado para la compra de gran cantidad de cuyes para incrementar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Rufino is 50 years old. He lives with his 25 year old son, and is his mother's carer. For 4 years he has worked selling guinea pigs in the main markets in his neighbourhood. He makes his sales every weekend and on the other days, with the help of his mother, he cares for and feeds his guinea pigs in the farm he has built in his house. Owing to the good care that he offers his animals, he has had good sales, because his guinea pigs are of a good size and weight. In the near future, Rufino wants to expand his farm and improve the breed of his animals so he can move forward with his sales. This is the third time he has had a loan with MFP. His commitment during these 2 years of work in his communal bank is recognised by the other members and his desire is to continue to contribute the best for the wellbeing of his group. The money that he is seeking will be destined for the purchase of a large quantity of guinea pigs to increase his sales.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of guinea pigs

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Genesis Group 5

texts.en:
Andres N. is the group coordinator for Genesis Group 5, which is based in the La Higuera settlement outside El Seybo, Dominican Republic.

Andres is 55 years old and married with four children, ages 25, 23, 21, and 16. His wife is also a client of Kiva and Esperanza and, together, they run a small general store out of their home selling men's and women's clothing, vegetables, chicken, and other provisions to their neighbors in the rural sugarcane community (called a batey) of La Higuera.

Today, Andres is looking to take out his 5th loan from Kiva and Esperanza so he can buy more clothing items, such as pants, shirts, and skirts, and food supplies for his retail store.

Andres' story is illustrative of his fellow group members' experiences with Kiva and Esperanza International. He reports that his life has improved considerably since becoming a microfinance client, and he hopes to sustain and grow his business in the future. Thank you for supporting Andres and the other members of Genesis Group 5 with your loan!

loans.use: To buy new clothing and food items to sell in his retail business

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur a eu la bonne idée de commencer en 2007 le commerce des insecticides, herbicides et divers. Ce commerce marche bien pour lui et il vend beaucoup surtout en cette période de pluie, où les insectes et les moustiques dérangent énormément. La demande de ses clients est élevée, il voudrait agrandir son stock pour mieux vendre, il demande à WAGES un crédit pour acheter des insecticides, herbicides et d’autres  produits.
Il est marié et père de 02 enfants.
texts.en:
In 2007, this gentleman had the good idea of beginning selling insecticides, herbicides, etc. The business is going well and he sells a lot, especially during the rainy season, where insects and flies are enormously bothersome. The demand of his customers is high, so he would like to expand his inventory to make more sales. He is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy insecticides, herbicides, and other products.

He is married and has 2 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of insecticides, herbicides and such

loans.name: Hanifa's Group

texts.en: Hanifa K., a tailor in Buwola, is a hard-working lady who is proud of her livelihood since it provides for her family's needs including the school fees for her children. The loans she has been receiving from Pearl Microfinance for nine years have allowed her business to steadily progress.  Hanifa now has three sewing machines, a bicycle, goats and a cow, none of which would have been possible without the loan support. She makes children’s wear, bitenge dresses, and gomesis, and she is blessed that customers go to her for their needs. Hanifa now needs a loan to help buy more clothing materials for sewing.

loans.use: Buying clothing materials for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Maria Ines

texts.en:
Maria Ines J. C. was born and raised in Boane, and continues to live there happily. She is 31 years old, and is married with two children, aged eight and ten. Maria studied through the 6th grade, but was forced to stop as her parents could not continue to afford to send her to school.

Maria works alone, selling products from a stand in Boane. Her best-selling products are peanuts and beans. With this loan she will help finance the purchase of construction materials for her home. This will be the first loan Maria has taken out with Kiva partner, Hluvuku-Adsema.

loans.use: To buy construction materials for her home

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia A. is a 64-year-old married mother of six children, three sons and three daughters. All of them have finished school and are currently working. Afia lives with her husband and some of her children in a rented apartment in the commercial town of Dwenase in the Western Region. Dwenase is a suburb of Sefwi-Wiawso, the district capital.

Afia and her husband are both traders. Afia has been in business for over 40 years and trades in food items such as vegetables, oil, rice, cereals, etc., which she supplies to food vendors. She buys her goods from Kumasi and nearby communities, and is requesting a loan to buy goods in bulk. Afia aspires to expand her business and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy food items in bulk

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin A. is a 44-year-old married father of five children, one son and four daughters. His children are currently in senior high, junior high and primary schools. Benjamin lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in the commercial town of Dwenase in the Western Region.

Benjamin's wife is a trader and he is a carver. Benjamin carves artifacts, such as dolls, out of logs of wood that he buys from nearby communities. He sells his wares at the local market and treks to sell, as well as supplying other retailers. Benjamin has been in business for over 15 years and wants a loan to buy logs and other working materials. He aspires to expand his business and sponsor his children in school.

loans.use: To buy logs of wood for carving

loans.name: Nailina

texts.en:
Nailina M. is originally from the town of Moamba. After the Mozambican civil war ended, she moved to Boane in 1994 in search of better living conditions and opportunities for her children. She supports her two children and sends money home to her mother in Moamba.

Nailina is a temporary employee at the administrative building in Boane, where she works as a janitor. This will be her fifth loan with Kiva partner, Hluvuku-Adsema; she has paid back the other four successfully. Nailina intends on using this loan to realize her dream of finalizing the construction of her home.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for her home

loans.name: Mustapha

texts.en:
Mustapha A. is a 50-year-old married father of three children, one son and two daughters. His children are currently in junior high and primary schools. Mustapha lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in the commercial town of Dwenase in the Western Region.

Mustapha's wife is a trader and he is a butcher. He sells meat, such as beef and mutton, in a shop in the market square. He buys livestock all the way from the northern part of the country, and supplies it to food vendors and restaurant operators in his community. He has been in business for over 25 years and wants a loan to buy cattle, sheep, goats, etc. in bulk. He aspires to expand his business and sponsor his children in school.

loans.use: To buy livestock

loans.name: Agnes' Group

texts.en: Agnes N. has been the leader of the Kamu Kamu women’s group in Lugazi for two years. She is 35 years old and married with six children. Agnes has been in business for three years selling new clothes as a hawker. She is requesting a loan in order to expand her business by purchasing new clothes. This will enable her to continue to pay her children's school fees. Agnes' dream is to buy a plot of land where she can construct her own house. She is happy that she is able to service her loans as they are beneficial to her and her family.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: Mahamadu S. is 30 years old, married and lives with his wife in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Dwenase in Ghana's Western Region. His wife is a trader, while Mahamadu works as a butcher, supplying meat to food vendors and restaurant operators. For the last 15 years, he has bought livestock in the northern part of the country and sold beef, mutton and other types of meat in a shop in his town's market square. He is applying for this loan to buy cattle, sheep, goat and other animals bulk. He aspires to expand his business and improve his standard of living.

loans.use: To buy livestock

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Rosalina U. M. is 47 years old and the mother of three children between the ages of 16 and 25. She lives in Boane, where she also helps support her widowed sister. For the last 27 years, Rosalina has worked both day and night in a corner shop, selling goods of various kinds. She plans to use this loan, her second from Hluvku, to finish building her home. She successfully paid back her first loan, which she also used to help build her home.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies

loans.name: Rc Primary School, Pamlap Group

texts.en:
These are the teachers of the RC Primary School in Pamlap village, which is located on the outskirts of Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. RC Primary School was built during the 1973/74 academic year by the local community with help from the Catholic Church, and has a total of 14 staff members and 546 pupils. 

RC Primary School, like many other schools in this country, lacks adequate teaching and learning materials and is very short on accommodations. Despite that, its students do well in National Primary School Examinations. The school has also recently linked up with an English school as part of an exchange program, and organizes annual athletics events for its pupils.

Mosses A. K. (below, second from left) is the head master at the school. He was born in Yele, in the Tonkolili district in northern Sierra Leone. He is married and has eight children. One of his children is grown, two are in college, two are in secondary schools and three in primary schools. Mosses has been a teacher for 44 years, and plans to use this loan to pay school fees for his children. “This loan is very big help,” he told me. “It is not easy to get someone to give you a loan in Sierra Leone, and teachers’ salaries are small,” he added. "If I can secure this loan, it will be a big relief for me."

loans.use: To pay his children's school fees

loans.name: Sanny

texts.en: Sanny O. is 24 years old and single. He lives  in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Dwenase in Ghana's Western Region. Sanny makes a living trading in salt, buying bags from the distributors who sell them from trucks. He sells these goods in the market square in his community. Sanny also supplies salt to food vendors and retailers, and travels to other towns to sell on their market days. He has been in this line of business for three years, and wants a loan to buy more goods in bulk. His goal is to expand his business and improve his standard of living.

loans.use: To buy salt in bulk

loans.name: Harriet's Group

texts.en: B. Harriet is the leader of a loan group called Kamu kamu. She is hard working and very friendly, and makes a living selling poultry and maize.
