Doña María Auxiliadora Chávez tiene en su casa una pequeña venta de verduras, helados, refrescos, etc. Ella es madre de un hijo en edad escolar, ayuda a atender a los clientes y a cuidar el negocio. Tiene varios años de experiencia en este negocio y de esto mantiene a su hijo porque ella no tiene esposo.
Sueña con poder mejorar su casa y darle estudio a su hijo.

Doña Blanca Azucena es madre soltera de tres hijos adolescentes que estudian en la escuela cercana a su hogar, se dedica a la venta de cajetas al igual que su otra compañera, vende ambulante en las escuelas y comunidades cercanas. El crédito lo ocupó para comprar los ingredientes como azúcar, frutas, colorantes, etc.
Sueña poder crecer en su negocio para mejorar el nivel de vida de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Photo from left to right: Elena Patricia M. G., María Auxiliadora Chávez and Blanca Azucena G..
This group is from the Municipality of Tisma and they are women who are known for their businesses. They have a great deal of confidence in each other and work in solidarity.
Elena Patricia is a young married woman with a small child. She makes a living making and selling cajetas (caramel), manjares (delicacies), sweets, etc. She works with ADIM because one of their clients encouraged her to join a solidarity group. She then formed a group with two close friends and received the loan. Her husband works as a merchant in the market and sometimes as an assistant in any kind of work. She dreams of making improvements on her home and of having a cajetas stall in the Masaya market.
María Auxiliadora Chávez has a small store selling vegetables, ice cream, refreshments, etc. in her house. She is the mother of one school aged son who helps her serve customers and look after the business. She has several years experience working in this business, which helps her provide for her son since she does not have a husband. She dreams of making improvements on her home and giving her son an education.
Blanca Azucena is a single mother of three teenagers who attend school near their house. She sells cajetas, just like her colleague, at the schools and in nearby communities on foot. She used the loan to purchase ingredients like sugar, fruits, colourings etc. She dreams of expanding her business in order to improve her children's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make cajetas and sweets

loans.name: Eskimo Group

texts.es:
Foto De izquierda a derecha: Lester de los Angeles Gaitán Gaitán, Angela del Socorro Téllez y Fanny del Carmen López Tórrez.

Este grupo es originario del barrio Monte Fresco de la ciudad de masaya, son perswonas trabajadoras y bien conocidas entre ellos.

Don Lester de los Angeles es un joven señor que se dedica a la venta de esquimos de forma ambulante, vende en el mercado y en los barrios de Masaya, hace esta actividad desde muy joven y cuando se casó se dedicó totalmente a este negocio porque no encontraba trabajo, ahora tiene muchos clientes y de esto mantiene a su familia que está compuesta de cinco hijos y su esposa. Sueña con poder darle educación a sus hijos, ellos estudian en la escuela cercana a su casa.Es el coordinador del grupo para este ciclo.

Doña Angela del Socorro tiene una pequeña pulpería en su casa, con lo que ayuda a su esposo con los gastos, tiene muchos años de experiencia, sus hijos le ayudan a atender la venta, están en edades adolescentes y dos pequeños. Ella sueña con poder mejorar su casa.

Doña Fanny del Carmen vende quesillos de forma ambulante, sale a vender a otros departamentos del país, compra estos quesillos en el mercado de Masaya, ofrece su producto a  buen precio y por eso sus ventas se han incrementado, el crédito lo ocupó para comprar mas quesillos y tortillas.
Tiene como meta mejorar su casa para darle mejores condiciones a su hijo.
texts.en:
Photo from left to right: Lester de los Angeles Gaitán Gaitán, Angela del Socorro Téllez y Fanny del Carmen López Tórrez. This group is from the Monte Fresco neighborhood in the city of Masaya. They are hard working people who know each other very well. Lester de los Angeles is a young man who works as a street vendor selling ice cream sandwiches. He sells in the market and the Masaya neighborhoods. He has been doing this since he was very young. When he got married he worked at this full time because he could not find other work. He now has lots of customers. This is how he supports his family, which consists of five children and his wife. He dreams of being able to give his children an education. His children go to a school near their house. He is the coordinator of the group for this cycle. Angela de Socorro has a small convenience store in her house, which is how she helps her husband with the household expenses. She has many years of experience. Her children help her with the sales. They are adolescents and two are small. She dreams of being able to improve her house. Fanny del Camren sells cheese as a street vendor. She sells in other departments of the country. She buys the cheese in the Masaya market. She sells her products at a good price, and her sales have been increasing. She used the loan to buy more cheese and tortillas. Her goal is to improve her house in order to give her son better living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ice cream sandwiches, cheese, and other things

loans.name: El Atardecer Group

texts.es:
Foto De izquierda a derecha: Ileana Janina López V., Meylin Juliet López  y Yamilet del Socorro V. Rodríguez.

Este grupo es originario de Masaya, son conocidas y de mucha confianza, son mujeres trabajadoras conocidas por la actividad que realizan.

Doña Ileana Janina es la coordinadora del grupo, ella se dedica a la elaboración de dulces variados como leche de burra, cajeta de leche, manjares, etc. esta actividad la aprendió de su mamá desde muy joven y cuando se casó se independizó con su propio negocio, tiene tres hijos de 10, 9  y  3 años, ellos están estudiando en la escuela cerca de la vivienda. Sueña con poder darles una mejor calidad de vida, su esposo le ayuda con los gastos, él es comerciante de ropa.

Doña Meylin Juliet al igual que su compañera se dedica a la elaboración de dulces y los vende en su casa, le ayuda una hermana a trabajar, tiene un hijo pequeño de un año, ella lo cuida y hace los quehaceres del hogar, su esposo trabaja en una empresa en Managua en el área eléctrica. Se siente orgullosa de poder generar sus propios ingresos.

Doña Yamilet del Socorro, tiene una pequeña pulpería desde hace varios años, tiene un pequeño niño al que ella atiende y a su negocio. Su esposo le ayuda con los gastos , él es ebanista en madera. Ella compra sus productos en el mercado de Masaya y se propone a que su pulpería ofrezca de todo tipo de productos.

Este grupo está comprometido con quedar bien en sus créditos y seguir trabajando para engrandecer su negocio.
texts.en:
Photo from left to right: Ileana Janina López V., Meylin Juliet López y Yamilet del Socorro V. Rodríguez. This group is from Masaya. They know and trust each other very much. They are hard working women who are known for their work. Illeana Janina is the coordinator of the group. She makes various sweets like “cajeta de leche” (a very popular candy in Latin America made of milk and sugar) and other regional delicacies. She learned how to do this when she was very young from her mother. When she got married, she started her own business. She has three children ages 10, 9, and 3. The go to the school that is near their home. She dreams of being able to give her children a better quality of life. Her husband helps with the expenses. He sells clothes. Meylin Juliet, just like her colleague, makes and sells sweets in her house. Her sister helps her with her work. She has a small, one year old son. She takes care of him and the house. Her husband works in a business in Managua in the electrical area. She is proud to be able to generate her own income. Yamilet del Socorro has had a small convenience store for several years. She has a small son that she takes care of along with her business. Her husband helps with the expenses. He makes wood cabinets. She buys her products in the Masaya market, and she wants her store to offer all types of products. This group is committed to being in good standing with their loans and to continue working to expand their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients to make sweets

loans.name: Matilde Raymunda

texts.es:
La señora Matilde pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Poderosas de Santa Rosa” que esta ubicado en el distrito de Azangaro, Provincia de Azangaro, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 53 años de edad, de estado civil casada, es madre de 05 hijos y  tiene estudios de secundaria incompleta (3er grado),  vive en el Barrio Revolución.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 01 años, con un préstamo inicial de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles el cual utilizó para la compra de lana. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 500.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de lanas de diferentes colores y calidades y así surtir mejor su tienda.

Su deseo es ampliar su tienda y surtirla mejor.

A ella le gusta la forma de trabajo del Banco Comunal.
texts.en:
Maltilde belongs to the Las Poderosas de Santa Rosa Community Bank, which is located in the Azangaro district, Azangaro province, Puno department. She is 53, married, and she has five children. She has three years of high school studies. She lives in the Revolución neighborhood. She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for one year. She used her original loan of 300 PEN to buy wool. She now needs a loan for 500 PEN to buy different colors and quantities of wool to better stock her store. Her wish is to expand her store and stock it better. She likes the way her community bank works.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wool

loans.name: Elizabeth Angelica

texts.es:
La señora Elizabeth, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Poderosas de Santa Rosa”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Azangaro, Provincia de Azangaro, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 38 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, es madre de 03 hijos y tiene estudios de primaria completa,  vive en el Barrio Revolución.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela R. desde hace 02 años, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles el cual utilizó para la compra golosinas y gaseosas. 

Con este préstamo de S/. 500.00 Nuevos soles, comprará caramelos, galletas, gaseosas, chocolates, etc.

Su deseo es comprarse un carro. A ella le gustan los ahorros ylas charlas que dan en el  Banco Comunal.
texts.en:
Mrs. Elizabeth belongs to the “Las Poderosas de Santa Rosa (The Powerful Women of Saint Rose)” Communal Bank which is located in the Azangaro district, Azangaro province, in the region of Puno. She is 38 years old, has a civil marriage, is the mother of three children, and completed elementary school. She lives in Barrio Revolucion (Revolution neighborhood). She has worked with the Manuela R. movement for two years. Her first loan was for 500 PEN and was used to purchase candies and sodas. With this loan of 500 PEN she will purchase caramels, cookies, sodas, chocolates, etc. Her desire is to buy herself a car. She likes the savings and the chats that they give at the communal bank.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of caramels, cookies, sodas, chocolates, etc.

loans.name: Veronica Magdalena

texts.es:
La señora Veronica Magdalena, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Poderosas de Santa Rosa”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Azangaro, Provincia de Azangaro, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 31 años de edad, de estado civil casada, es madre de 02 hijos y tiene estudios de educación superior (Enfermera),  vive en el Barrio Lisandro Luna.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace casi 02 años, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, dicho dinero lo utilizó para la compra de medicinas para implementar su botica. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 1100.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de diferentes medicinas.

Su deseo es comprarse una casa en Juliaca. A ella le gustan los ahorros y las reuniones de los Bancos Comunales.
texts.en:
Mrs. Veronica Magdalena, belongs to the community bank Las Poderosas de Santa Rosa (The Powerful of Santa Rosa) which is located in the district of Azangaro, Azangaro Province, Department of Puno. She is 31 years old, is married, and is the mother of two children. She is studying to become a nurse. She lives in the neighborhood Lisandro Luna. She has worked with Movimiento Manuel Ramos for almost two years. Her first loan was for $165 (500 PEN). She used the money to buy medicines to stock her pharmacy. Now, she requires a loan of $375 (1100 PEN) to buy different medicines. Her goal is to buy a house in Juliaca. She likes the savings and the meetings of community banks.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Trad, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy medicines

loans.name: Luz Gregoria

texts.es:
La señora Luz pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Poderosas de Santa Rosa”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Azangaro, Provincia de Azangaro, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 38 años de edad, es madre soltera, y tiene 01 hijo, tiene estudios de educación superior (profesora de matemáticas),  vive en el Barrio Revolución.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 02 años, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles el cual utilizó para la compra de artesanías. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 800.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de lanas para elaborar artesanías, como animalitos (títeres) por pedido, también  tejer colchas.

Su deseo es formar un grupo  de mujeres para elaborar artesanías.

A ella le gustan los ahorros, los encuentros del Banco Comunal.
texts.en:
Ms Luz belongs to “The Powerful of Santa Rosa” cooperative bank that is located in Azangaro, Azangaro Province, Department of Puno. She is 38 years old, and a single mother with one child. She has an advanced education and was a math teacher. She lives in the community called “Revolution”. Ms Luz has worked with the Manuela Ramos group for the past two years. Her first loan was for three hundred soles, which she used to buy folk-art. At this time, Ms Luz would like a loan for eight hundred soles in order to buy wool to make her folk-art. She makes little animal puppets on request and also weaves blankets. She would like to organize a group of women who would make crafts. She likes the savings she gets from the cooperative bank.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wool for her weavings

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ysmelda Edita

texts.es:
La señora Ysmelda Edita tiene 49 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Salaverry, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudio secundarios completos, tiene 6 hijos de los cuales 2 dependen de ella económicamente. 
Ysmelda se dedica a atender su peluquería que se encuentra ubicada en su mismo domicilio.
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió del Banco Comunal  “Las Emprendedoras II”, lo invirtió en la compra de tijeras, líquidos de ondulación, gorros, chalecos, etc
Con este crédito de S/. 800 soles lo invertirá en comprar una secadora de pelo, tijeras y pintara su local.
Ysmelda  tiene como sueño captar más clientes y llegar a tener una peluquería en Trujillo.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ysmelda Edita is 49 years old and lives in the Salaverry district of Trujillo province, department of La Libertad, Peru. This businesswoman completed her high school education. She has six children, two of which are still financially dependent on her. Ysmelda works from of her home as a hairdresser. With her first loan of 300 soles from her communal bank called "Las Entrepreneurs II", she purchased scissors, perming lotions, disposable hair caps, barbers capes, etc. With her current loan of 800 soles, she will purchase a hair dryer and scissors, as well as have her business premises painted. Ysmelda’s dream is to attract more customers and to have her own beauty shop in Trujillo.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a hair dryer and scissors; maintenance her business premises

loans.name: Teresa De Jesus

texts.es:
La señora Teresa D. Jesús tiene 59 años D. edad, vive en el distrito D. Salaverry, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudios D. primaria completa, tiene 6 hijos y ninguno depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Teresa se dedica  a apoyar a  sus hijos y esposo en la pesca colaborando con la compra D. materiales D. pescar, mantenimiento y reparación del barco.
Con el primer crédito D. 300 soles que recibió del Banco Comunal  “Las Emprendedoras II”, lo invirtió en la compra D. materiales para tejer las redes D. pescar junto con el apoyo D. sus hijos y esposo.
Con este crédito D. S/ 1,200 lo invertirá en la compra D. mas redes D. pescar ya que las que tiene actualmente se encuentran deterioradas y su familia depenD. D. la pesca para vender y obtener dinero para sus gastos.
Teresa  tiene como sueño, tejer mas redes D. pescar, comprar pinturas y darle mantenimiento  a su barco para que este listo dentro D. 3 meses que empezara la pesca.
texts.en:
Teresa D. Jesús is 59 years old and lives in Salaverry district, in Trujillo province, in the department of La Libertad, Peru. She is a businesswoman who completed her primary school education and has 6 children, none of whom are financially dependent on her. Teresa works supporting her children and her husband in their fishing business - she contributes to the purchase of fishing equipment along with the maintenance and repair of their boat. She used the first loan of 300 soles she received from “Las Emprendedoras II” Communal Bank to invest in the purchase of materials for making fishing nets, together with the support of her children and her husband. She will use the current loan of 1,200 soles to invest in the purchase of more fishing nets, because the nets she currently has have deteriorated, and her family depends on fishing as their livelihood so they can earn money to make ends meet. Teresa’s goal is to make more fishing nets, purchase paint, and do maintenance on their boat so that it will be ready for her family to begin fishing again within 3 months.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investing in the purchase of material for making fishing nets

loans.name: Rojo Group

texts.es:
Foto De izquierda a derecha :  Juana María A. M., Sandra del Socorro J. Velásquez  y  Eugenia Martínez.

Doña Juana María es comerciante de sandalias de mujer, ofrece en todos los estilos, ella comercializa en los departamentos de Rivas, Managua y Masaya. Le ayuda su esposo con los gastos de la casa, trabaja en una zona franca. Tiene a su cargo dos hijos. Sueña con mejorar su casa y dar un mejor nivel de vida a sus hijos.

Doña Sandra del Socorro es la coordinadora del grupo, es persona muy responsable y líder del grupo. Se dedica a la venta de ropa interior y cosméticos, tiene muchos clientes que le piden encargos para sus hijos y familia. El préstamo lo ocupa en comprar ropa por docena en el mercado Oriental de Managua, compra ropa de mujer y de niño porque es la que mas vende.
Ella sueña con mejorar algunas partes de su casa y tener mejores ingresos.

Eugenia Martínez vende zapatos de forma ambulante, le ayuda su hijo que ya es joven, se dividen zonas de los departamentos para vender más, ella compra el calzado en los talleres de Masaya a buen precio, tiene muchos clientes. Su esposo le ayuda con los gastos del hogar porque trabaja como obrero en una zona franca.
Ella sueña con poder tener mías clientes para su producto y ayudar a su hijo a estudiar
texts.en:
Photo from left to right: Juana María A. M., Sandra del Socorro J. Velásquez and Eugenia Martínez.
Juana María sells women’s sandals in all styles. She works in the Rivas, Managua and Masaya districts. Her husband helps her cover household expenses and works in a free trade zone; they have two children. She dreams of making improvements on her home and improving her children’s quality of life.
Sandra del Socorro is the group coordinator. She is a very responsable person and leads the group. She sells underwear and cosmetics, and has many customers who make orders for their children and families. She is using the loan to purchase garments by the dozen in Managua’s Oriental market. She buys women’s and children’s clothing because they are the most profitable. She dreams of making improvements on parts of her house and of increasing her income.
Eugenia Martínez sells shoes as a street vendor and her son, who is already a young man, helps her. They divide up the district zones in order to make more sales. She buys footwear from the Masaya shoemakers at a good price, and has many customers. Her husband helps her pay the bills because he works as a labourer in a free trade zone. She dreams of having more customers and of supporting her son’s studies.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing and shoes to sell as street vendors

loans.name: Candy Selene

texts.es:
La señora Candy S. F.   tiene 27 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Salaverry, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudios de secundaria completa, tiene 2hijos que dependen de ella económicamente.
Candy se dedica a la venta de cerveza en su domicilio.
Este es su primer crédito de 300 soles compro mas materiales como: hilos, telas, alambres, perlas, etc.  para que pueda hacer sus manualidades 
Con el crédito de 1.000 soles que será cancelado en 6meses, lo invertirá en su negocio, en la compra de más cervezas.
Candy   tiene como sueño hacer una micro empresa de manualidades y almohadas con el apoyo de su madre y de sus hermanas.
texts.en:
Ms Candy is twenty-seven years old and lives in the community of Salaverry, in the Trujillo province, in the department of La Libertad, Peru. This businesswoman has completed her secondary education. She has two children who are economically dependent on her. Candy sells beer from her home. With her first loan, of three hundred soles, she bought materials such as thread, fabric, wire, pearls, etc. in order to make handicrafts. With the loan of one thousand soles, due in six months, she will invest in her business by buying more beer. Candy’s dream is to start a small business making handicrafts and pillows with the assistance of her mother and her sisters.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase more cases of beer

loans.name: Ruth

texts.es:
La señora Ruth, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Flor Azangarina II”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Azangaro, Provincia de Azangaro, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 28 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, es madre de 02 hijos y tiene estudios de secundaria completa,  vive en el Barrio Lisandro Luna.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 02 años, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles,  el cual utilizó para la compra de útiles de escritorio. 

Con este préstamo de S/. 800.00 Nuevos soles, comprará útiles de escritorio como cuadernos, papel, lapicero, fólderes, etc. 

Su mayor sueño es poder ampliar su tienda y continuar trabajando para darles educación a sus hijos.

A ella le gustan los ahorros y la facilidad para obtener préstamos con bajos intereses.
texts.en:
Ruth belongs to the community bank “Flor Azangarina II” (Azangarine Flower II), which is located in the Azangaro district of Azangaro province, in the department of Puno. She is 28-years old, has a live-in partner and is the mother of 2 children. Ruth has completed secondary education and currently lives in the neighborhood of Lisandro Luna. She has worked with Movimiento Manuela Ramos for 2 years. Her first loan was for 500 PEN, which she used to buy office/school supplies. With this loan of 800 PEN, Ruth will buy office supplies such as notebooks, papers, pens, folders, etc. Her biggest dream is to be able to expand her store and continue working so that she can provide her children with a good education. Ruth likes to save and be able to take out loans with low interest.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of office supplies: notebooks, paper, pens, folders, etc.

loans.name: Angelitos Group

texts.es:
Foto De izquierda a derecha :  Gloria Isabel C. Gaitán , Araceli del Carmen P. R. y Socorro de los Angeles José F..

Este grupo es originario de Masaya, son conocidas y de mucha confianza, son mujeres trabajadoras conocidas por la actividad que realizan.

Doña Gloria Isabel se dedica a vender productos varios en su casa, como tortillas, tamales, cuajadas, queso, etc. ella los compra y los vende, este negocio tiene 8 años de tenerlo para ayudar con los gastos del hogar. Su esposo le ayuda, él es panadero.
Solo tiene un hijo al que piensa darle estudio, sueña con mejorar su casa y tener un espacio solo para su negocio.

Araceli del Carmen tiene un pequeño taller de calzado junto con su esposo, ambos lo tienen desde que se casaron, tienen dos hijos que le ayudan en el taller, venden los zapatos a personas que tienen tramos en el mercado. Juntos piensan en darle estudios a sus hijos.
Socorro de los Angeles  al igual que su compañera tiene un pequeño taller de calzado junto con su esposo, se especializa en sandalias de mujer con trenzas, ella espera poder crecer mas en su negocio y mejorar el área del taller porque está descubierta. Tiene dos hijos que estudian.
El crédito lo necesita para comprar materiales de zapatería
texts.en:
Photo from left to right: Gloria Isabel C. G. , Araceli del Carmen P. R. and Socorro de los Angeles J. F..

This group is originally from Masaya. They hard working women who are trustworthy and well known through their businesses.

Gloria Isabel isells various products from her home, such as tortillas, tamales, jellies, cheese etc. She buys them and then resells them. She has been running the business for 8 years and it has helped her cover the household expenses. Her husband also contributes. He is a baker. She has only one child and she hopes to provide him with an education. She dreams of improving her home and to have a dedicated space for her business.

Araceli del Carmen has a small cobbler shop together with her husband. They have been running it since they got married. They have two children and they both help out in the shop. They sell shoes to the local merchants in the market. They hope to provide their children with an education.

Socorro de los Angeles, as her colleague, she has a cobbler shop together with her husband. She specializes in weaved sandals for women. She hopes to be able to expand her business and to move her shop to a better location that is sheltered. She has two children, both are in school.

The loan that is requested is to purchase shoe-making supplies.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase shoe-making supplies.

loans.name: Digna Emerita

texts.es:
la sra. Digna Emerita H. tiene 4 años de dedicarse a la venta de ropa nueva, este tipo de actividad lo realiza de forma domiciliar y ambulante en diferentes comunidades y caserios aledaños de Santa Maria, ella es casada y madre de 5 hijos los cuales todos dependen del matrimonio, su esposo se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería.-  con los ingresos que le genera la venta de ropa
ella cubre sus gastos personales y tambien le colabora a su esposo a cubrir algunos gastos familiares. la meta de ella es poder ver graduados a sus hijos de la universidad y que sean hombres de bien.
texts.en:
For four years Ms Digna has sold new clothes. She sells the clothes from her home and also in other towns and neighboring hamlets near Santa Maria. She is married and has five children who are dependent upon her and her husband. Her husband works in agriculture and ranching. With the profits from her business, Ms Digna pays for her personal expenses and also helps her husband pay for the family’s expenses. Her goals are to be able to see her children graduate from University and to become good people.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase new clothes for women and children

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Maria Emilia

texts.es: la sra Maria Emilia M. ella se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo popular, tiene una  pequeña pulperia en la cual vende pocas cosas ya que no tiene el capital suficiente para poderla surtir como se debe, ademas tiene un año y medio de haber iniciado con su negocio, tambien vende recargas para llamadas de celular, es casada y madre de 2 hijos que todavia dependen del matrimonio, su esposo se dedica a la agricultura.- con los ingresos que el negocio le genera, ella cubre sus gastos personales y tambien le ayuda a su esposo con los gastos del hogar.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Emilia M. sells popular household products from her small grocery store. She is only able to sell a few items because she does not have sufficient capital to keep her store as well stocked as she would like. A year and a half after she started her business, she also began selling rechargeable mobile phone cards.

Maria Emilia is married and the mother of 2 dependent children. Her husband is a farmer. With the earnings generated from her business, she is able to cover her personal expenses as well as assist her husband with household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy soap, beans, bread, rice, sugar, coffee, cookies, chips, soup, and toilet paper

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
la sra. Norma C. Nierto se dedica a la venta de carnes, como ser carne de res, cerdo y pollo, actividad que inicio en su casa de habitación y despues empezo a vender de manera ambulante, mi 
compañero de hogar se dedica a la agricultura, y tenemos 3 hijos que dependen de nosotros, ahora cuanto con el apoyo de mi compañero de hogar en el negocio ya que el sale a vender en su moto despues que sale de trabajar a diferentes comunidades y cacerios cercanas a Santa Maria, con los ingresos que me genera el negocio cubro mis gastos personales y aporto a mi esposo a cubrir algunos gastos del hogar. Norma en estos momentos necesita el credito para poder salir adelante.
texts.en:
Norma C. Nierto sells beef, pork and chicken products, initially selling from her home and later selling from a handcart: "My partner works in agriculture and we have 3 dependent children. Now, he helps me with my business; after finishing his work he goes to sell the meat in different communities and towns near Santa Maria in his motorcycle. With the income the business earns I can cover my personal expenses and help my husband with household expenses." Norma currently needs a loan in order to advance her business.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of beef, pork and chicken

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Martina Andrea

texts.es:
La señora Martina Andrea L. V.  tiene 46 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Salaverry , provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria tiene estudio secundarios completos, tiene 4 hijos de los cuales 2 están a su cargo.
Martina se dedica a la venta de menús (alimentos)los cuales los prepara en su domicilio. Luego son repartidos a sus comensales.

El primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió del Banco Comunal  “Las Emprendedoras II”, lo invirtió en la compra insumos como arroz, fideos, azúcar, menestras ,ajos , ají, rocoto, aceite , carne , pollo, etc     
Con este crédito de 500 soles comprará insumos al por mayor así como utensilios de cocina  que requiere su negocio.
Juana tiene como sueño, incrementar su negocio para obtener más ganancias y seguir con la construcción de cuartos en su domicilio para luego ponerlos en alquiler.
texts.en:
La señora Martina Andrea L. V. is 46 years old. She lives in the district of Salaverry, Trujillo Province, La Libertad Department, Perú. The businesswoman has studied secondary school, and has 4 children, 2 of whom are in her care. Martina works selling food, which she prepares in her home. The food is then distributed to customers. The first loan of 300 soles she received from the Banco Comunal 'Las Emprendedoras II' she invested in the purchase of consumables such as rice, pasta, sugar, lentils, garlic, chili, hot peppers, oil, meat, chicken etc. With this loan of 500 soles she will buy consumables because they are the biggest utensils of the kitchen that she requires in her business. Her dream is to increase her business to be able to obtain more earnings and continuing constructing the rooms in her house to later rent them out.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of consumables such as rice, oil, lentils, pasta etc to prepare food

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna A. is from the village of Labuyo in Tangub City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is 52 years old. Myrna is married and has two infants. To make a living, Myrna sells fish. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Myrna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which she will use to purchase additional fish to expand her product offering. This is Myrna's first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Cuen- Las Rositas Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Las Rositas es un grupo de 10 socias que viven en la comunidad de Ingapirca, aproximadamente media hora fuera de la ciudad de Cuenca en el sur de Ecuador. Es un grupo que recién se formó hace menos de dos años, pero las socias han sido muy cumplidas y responsables y el banco casi se maneja solo, sin mucha ayuda de su promotora de crédito. 

Son señoras muy cálidas y cariñosas, y están muy animadas con ser uno de los primeros bancos comunales de la Fundación ESPOIR para entrar a Kiva. La mayoría de las socias se dedican a la agricultura y la ganadería. 

Por ejemplo, la señora Maria tiene 25 años y vive con su pareja y su hijo de 5 años. Ella trabaja en la casa cuidando a su hijo y criando cuyes y gallinas; actualmente tiene 40 cuyes y 36 gallinas. Está pidiendo un crédito de $150 para poder construir pequeñas casas para sus gallinas, porque si no se las cuida bien se mueren o ya no ponen huevos. Su meta para el futuro es construir una casa para su familia; actualmente está viviendo en la casa de sus suegros. Ella nunca había sacado un crédito antes de conocer a la Fundación ESPOIR, y dice que no conoce ninguna otra institución que ofrece préstamos en su comunidad. 

La señora Maria Asunción tiene 35 años y es casada con un hijo de 5 años. Ella siembra hortalizas como zanahorias, cebollas y ajo, y también cría animales. Actualmente tiene 30 cuyes, 15 gallinas y una vaca. A veces vende sus verduras en el mercado de Cuenca; viaja cada dos semanas a la ciudad para vender. Ella está pidiendo un préstamo de $100 para invertir en la compra de semillas de zanahoria y cebolla y la compra de abono para sus terrenos. Este es su tercer crédito con su banco comunal, y dice que entró al grupo porque le conviene, como su promotora viene al pueblo mismo para hacer las reuniones y entregar los créditos. Su meta para el futuro es poner una cría de pollos con pollos de la ciudad (en vez de pollos del campo, los cuales está criando actualmente). Los pollos de la ciudad son un poco más complicados para criar, nos cuenta, porque son más delicados, pero crecen rápido y son de mejor calidad, por ende ganaría mas al venderlos. 

Otras socias usarán sus préstamos para comprar abono para sus terrenos y para comprar crías de chanchos. El grupo está muy comprometido con pagar este préstamo de manera puntal y responsable.
texts.en:
The Las Rositas Communal Bank is a group of 10 members who live in the Ingapirca community, about a half hour outside the city of Cuenca in southern Ecuador. The group formed relatively recently less than two years ago, but the members have been very reliable and responsible. The bank practically runs itself without too much help from their loan officer.
They are very warm, kind-hearted women, and are very eager to be one of Fundación ESPOIR’s top communal banks to join Kiva. Most of the members work in agriculture and cattle farming.
For example, Maria is 25 years old and lives with her partner and 5-year-old son. She works at home, looking after her son and raising guinea pigs and chickens. She currently has 40 guinea pigs and 36 chickens. She is requesting a $150 loan to build a chicken coop because if they aren’t well looked after they die or don’t lay eggs. Her future goal is to build a house for her family; she currently lives in the house of her in-laws. She had never taken out a loan before finding out about Fudación ESPOIR and says that she doesn’t know of any other credit institutions in her community.
Maria Asunción is 35 years old and married with a 5-year-old son. She grows vegetables like carrots, onions and garlic, and also raises animals. She currently has 30 guinea pigs, 15 chickens and one cow. She sometimes sells her produce at the Cuenca market; she travels to the city every two weeks to sell there. She is requesting a $100 loan to purchase carrot and onion seeds, and fertiliser for her land. This is her third loan with her communal bank. She says that she joined the group because it suited her well and her loan officer comes to the town to run the meetings and distribute the loans. Her future goal is to raise a flock of chickens from the city (instead of the country chickens she currently raises). The chickens from the city are a little more difficult to raise, she says, because they are more delicate, but they grow quickly and are better quality, and therefore more profitable.
The other members will use their loans to purchase fertiliser and pigs. The group is very committed to being punctual and responsible in repaying this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase livestock and organic fertilisers for their crops

loans.name: Melisa

texts.en:
" I am expecting both good and failure every time I do business. That is why, I am making all the possibilities to increase the likelihood of success over failures. I owned a rice filed with an area of 1.5 hectare. And currently, our farm is in the process of land preparation before planting new seedlings of rice," says Melisa G., a 25-year-old mother of three children.

Coming form a poor family, she knows very well how hard it is to work on a farm. Now, she wants to make their farm grow even more. By applying a loan of Php 8,000 from CEVI, she thinks she will be able to do something to improve their yield. She intends to buy fertilizer, herbicides, and pesticides to protect her plants and have an abundant harvest.

She choose CEVI for its wide variety of services like insurance coverage and training.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, herbicides and insecticides

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
"We own a 2.5 hectare farm. We have been tilling the land since the start of our marriage. Up til now, farming is what keeps our family sustained. We use our harvest to have food on our table. We sell some of our grains to be able to buy the other things we need in our home," says Elizabeth A., a 35-year-old mother of three children.

"Being poor is not easy," she says. Now she wants to expand her farm. She is asking for a loan of 15,000 PHP to buy sacks of seeds, fertilizers and other farming supplies. She believes that this move will bring her good returns from her farm.

Elizabeth chose CEVI for its wide range of services. In addition to loans, she learns many things in their Christian nurturing program every cluster meeting. CEVI also provides insurance coverage to all its clients.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of seeds, fertilizers and other farming supplies

loans.name: Hernane

texts.en:
Hernane C. is a 21-year-old farmer from Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur--a poor community in Mindanao whose people are engaged in farming and raising animals like cows, goats, chickens and ducks. He has four children and is tilling a 2 hectare farm.

His dream is to make his farm productive. He needs the additional capital of 8,000 PHP to be able to buy complete fertilizers, herbicides and crude oil and to pay for the laborer on his farm. Income from the harvest is used to provide food for his children as well as pay for school and other needs in their home.

Hernane chose CEVI because of its wide range of services. CEVI helps him access loans for business improvement. In addition, he benefits from the insurance coverage that CEVI offers to all its clients.

loans.use: To purchase complete fertilizers, herbicides and crude oil, and to pay for labor

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda B. is a 43-year-old farmer from Libertad, Agusan del Sur. She is tilling a one-hectare farm that is her only source of livelihood to help her meet the needs of her family.

Currently, she is busy preparing her land; however, she needs additional capital to pay for the necessary expenses on her farm. She would like to ask for a loan worth Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to purchase insecticide, herbicide and fertilizer. The loan will help her improve her harvest and income for her family.

She chose CEVI for its wide range of services. At CEVI, it's not only about loans, but also business training, biblical reflections and insurance coverage given to all members.

loans.use: To purchase insecticide, herbicides and fertilizer

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
"We are a farmer since we are just small kids. My husband and I came from a farmer clan. From a very young age, we already familiar the kind of life growing rice and other crops to be able to provide food in the family" says Judith R., 42-year-old mother of four children.

Knowing the services of Community Economic Ventures, she never hesitated to apply for a loan worth Php 12,000. She will use the loan to purchase hybrid seeds, fertilizers and other farming needs. The loan will help her increase their harvest and income as well. 

She chose CEVI because of the easy credit access, training and insurance coverage that they offer to all their clients.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds, fertilizer and other farming needs.

His father taught him everything about farming from sowing the seeds to harvest. Now, he is tilling a 1 hectare farm to support his family.

He wants to make his farm more productive and he can only achieve that if he is able to buy the needed fertilizers and chemicals for his farm. He wants to borrow 10,000 PHP. This will be enough to improve his harvest.

He chose CEVI for its wide range of services. He receives insurance coverage as well as loans.

Because she thinks about maximizing her farm, she applied for a loan from CEVI worth Php 10,000. She will use the loan to purchase sacks of fertilizer and other farm needs. In this way, she believes she could make her farm productive.

Her next plan is to buy a turtle machine (farm equipment). Thru CEVI, she believes she can realize her dreams.

Because they are needing additional capital to run their business, Annie G. applied for a loan worth Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy certified seeds and fertilizer. She hopes that this move will help improve their harvest.

CEVI helps small business grow. According to Annie G., she received not just loans but insurance coverage as well.

His farming business has gone far in helping him pay for his children's tuition, books and other school fees, and provide for the things his family needs.

About CEVI
CEVI continues to help small farmers sustain their livelihoods. CEVI helps small business grow by providing credit, training, savings and insurance cover to all its clients.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, herbicides and other farm supplies

loans.name: Rizal

texts.en:
Rizal J. is 33 years old and has two children. He owns a three-hectare farm that has gone far in helping him to provide food and meet his family's other basic needs. He is doing his best to make his business flourish so that he can send his children to school and pay for their books and tuition.

The moment Rizal heard about the services of Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc., he never hesitated to apply for a loan. He is requesting the amount of 10,000 PHP to buy herbicides, fertilizers and other farm supplies. He thinks that this initiative will help him improve his harvest even more.

About CEVI
CEVI helps farmers sustain their livelihoods. It provides small loans, training and insurance cover to all its clients.

loans.use: To buy herbicides, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet C. is a rice grower. She is 41 this year and tills a one-hectare farm with her husband, Emelio C.. Her harvest pays for her family's basic needs. It also helps to pay for her children's books, tuition and other school fees.

Juliet became interested in the services offered by Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She was able to meet other small entrepreneurs and discuss their businesses. She is now applying for a loan of 10,000 PHP to buy two sacks of fertilizer, herbicide and other farm supplies. As well as credit, CEVI also offers insurance cover to all its clients.

loans.use: To purchase two sacks of fertilizer, herbicide and other farm supplies

loans.name: Rudy

texts.en:
Rudy R. is 47 years old and married to Rhodora. They have two children. Rudy has been in farming since he was a small child. He owns a one-hectare farm that has gone far in providing for his family's basic needs, such as food, clothing, medicine and education.

Rudy is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP from Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. The loan will help him buy fertilizers and insecticides to ensure an abundant harvest on his farm. Rudy is happy as an active member of CEVI. He enjoys not just credit assistance, but training and insurance cover as well.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and insecticides

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith R. is a 35-year-old farmer and mother of two children. She grows rice but also plants corn to provide an additional income for her family. Judith's husband, Jimmy, manages their 1.3-hectare farm. All of their harvest is intended for family consumption, but when there is an excess, the couple sell it to rice traders in their village.

Farming is what keeps the R. family together. Judith would like to improve her harvest by adopting the use of fertilizers and new insecticides. When she heard about Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures Inc., she immediately requested a loan of 10,000 PHP. She will use the loan to support the needs of her farm.

Judith's next target is to own a turtle machine, a type of farm equipment. She believes that she will be able to achieve her dreams with CEVI's help.

loans.use: To purchase two sacks of potash fertilizer and sacks of seeds

loans.name: Lito

texts.en:
Lito V. is a 37-year-old farmer from Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur, Mindanao. Lito wishes to improve the size and quality of his harvest, hoping to double or triple his yield, as his family depends on it. He is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc. He will use the loan to buy one sack of fertilizer and some herbicides.

About CEVI
CEVI helps small business grow. In the Philippines, it has reached more than 23,000 clients with its loan services as well as its training and insurance cover.

loans.use: To purchase one sack of fertilizer and some herbicides

loans.name: Happy

texts.en: Ms Happy M. is a poultry farmer with over 1000 chickens. She has been in the business of rearing chickens for over three years. She will use her loan to purchase more chicks, chicken feed, chicken medicines, etc., to improve her business. Happy has one child who is at school. With her poultry business, she is managing to look after her family successfully. Her future hope is to work hard and invest for her family, especially her daughter.

loans.use: To purchase more chicks, chicken feed, chicken medicines, etc.

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie B. is a 34-year-old mother of two from Bunawan, Agusan del Sur. She helps her husband till their 2.5-hectare rice field. Jessie dreams of sending all her children to college. That is why she and her husband are doing everything they can to improve and hopefully double their yield. Jessie is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP from Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. This will help improve the couple's yield as well as their income.

About CEVI
CEVI continues to reach out to poor communities, encouraging people to start and run a business of their own. CEVI provides its clients with credit assistance, training and insurance cover.

loans.use: To purchase seven sacks of fertilizer and other farming supplies

loans.name: Dalia

texts.en: Ms Dalia N. B. owns a private primary school with 200 pupils. She has been running the school for four years. Dalia will use her loan to stock the school library and to purchase other teaching materials, such as chalks, markers and blackboards. Her business dream is to provide the very best for the pupils and for her pupils to get many first grades. Her goal is to create the very best school there can be.

loans.use: To stock the library and purchase other teaching materials (chalks, markers, blackboards)

loans.name: Thuyisighagane Muhindo Gladesi Group

texts.en:
M. Gladesi is a 40-year-old married mother of seven children who all go to school. She also takes care of one dependant.

For the last three years Gladesi has been selling fish and cassava flour. She will use her loan to purchase more cassava flour and various types of fish to sell.

Gladesi also owns poultry and livestock to generate extra income. Her future hope is to construct a residential house.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava flour and various types of fish to sell

loans.name: Leonardo

texts.en:
To have an abundant harvest and own some farm machinery are the ultimate goals of Leonardo B., a farmer and father of four from Bunawan, Agusan del Sur. Now, Leonardo is busy preparing his land for the next planting. He is doing his best to grow his farm business to support all his family's needs.

Leonardo is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI. He will use the loan to purchase herbicides and fertilizers. The loan will help improve his harvest.

About CEVI
CEVI helps small business to grow. As well as offering loans, it gives its clients security through its micro-insurance program.

loans.use: To purchase herbicides and fertilizers

loans.name: Thuyisighagane Itungu Joyce Group

texts.en:
I. Joyce is a 50-year-old single mother of two children who are both in school. For over ten years Joyce has been selling palm oil and smoked fish. She will use her loan to purchase more palm oil and smoked fish so that she can expand her business and satisfy customer demand.

With the profits of her business, Joyce has managed to educate her children and buy a goat. Her future plan is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase more palm oil and smoked fish

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina O., a 36-year-old mother of three children, owns a one-hectare farm. She helps her husband, Drix O., to till the farm to ensure an abundant harvest for her family. The couple dream of good things for their children. They want to send them to school so that when they get older, they will find better employment and be able to provide for their future families.

Mrs O. is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP from Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI). She will use the loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and herbicides. The loan will help her achieve maximum yield from her farm and a better income for her family. As well as enjoying accessible credit from CEVI, Gina is secured by the CEVI micro-insurance program.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and herbicides

loans.name: Cooperative Biira Jane Group

texts.en:
Jane B. is 20 years old and a single mother of three children, two of whom are in school. She also takes care of four dependants.

Jane has operated a coffee business for over two years. She will use her loan to purchase coffee in greater volume to add capital to her business and increase her sales.

Jane is a very hardworking lady and lives as an example to others. Her future dream is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase coffee in greater volume

loans.name: Myrlen

texts.en:
Myrlen A. is a 31-year-old farmer and mother of four children. Grains are her main source of livelihood and her main crop is rice. She has been diligently helping her husband to obtain an abundant harvest. Their harvest is intended for family consumption and the rest is sold to their neighbors for additional income.

Myrlen would like a loan of 10,000 PHP from Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI). She will use the loan to purchase three sacks of seeds and fertilizers. Hopefully, these will help her to improve her harvest.

About CEVI
CEVI helps small business to grow. It provides loans and insurance cover services.

loans.use: To purchase three sacks of seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Cooperative Mwindo Zelefa Group

texts.en: Zelefa M., a 45-year-old businesswoman, is a single mother of four children and the care-giver of three dependents. The owner of a restaurant business for over ten years, she is requesting a loan to purchase restaurant items such as foodstuffs, charcoal, and drinks; generally she wants to improve on her dairy menu to satisfy her customers. Zelefa is a very hard-working woman whose dream is to construct her own premises.

loans.use: To purchase restaurant items such as foodstuffs, charcoal, and drinks.

loans.name: Kabughabugha Women Itungu Mary Group

texts.en: Mary I., a 20-year-old married mother of five children, three of whom are in school, has been in the business of selling cassava flour for over two years. She is requesting the loan to purchase bags of cassava which she will make into flour for sale. Mary is a hard-working young businesswoman whose hope is to open up a shop.

loans.use: To purchase bags of cassava to make into flour for sale.

loans.name: Celso

texts.en:
Celso L. is a 34-year-old rice grower who tills a 1.5-hectare farm. He wants to establish a sustainable livelihood and save something for his future family. He is making the most of every opportunity to earn a larger income so that he can buy more farmland. Soon he will settle down but before that happens, he will save all his earnings.

Celso is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP from Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI). He will use the loan to purchase necessary fertilizers and seeds. Hopefully, this will bring him a good return on his investment.

About CEVI
CEVI helps small farmers to sustain their livelihoods. CEVI gives loans, training and insurance cover to all its clients.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Kabughabugha Women Mbindule Jovia Group

texts.en: Jovia M. is 30 years old and married with five children, three of whom are in school. For the last three years, Jovia has been involved in buying and selling bananas. She will use her loan to purchase bananas in large quantities so that she can improve her business and make more profit. Jovia is a hardworking businesswoman and her future plan is to open a large retail shop.

loans.use: To purchase bananas in large quantities

loans.name: Enriquita

texts.en:
Enriquita P. is a 52-year-old rice grower with three children. In the past, Enriquita worried about how she was going to afford her huge family expenses. However, her partnership with Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI), gave her capital to sustain her one-hectare farm. CEVI also helped Enriquita start up a sari-sari store (convenience store) business.

This time, Enriquita wants to apply for a loan of 8,000 PHP from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy good-quality rice seeds as well as fertilizers. Hopefully, this will eventually give her a bountiful harvest from her farm.

About CEVI
CEVI helps small business to grow. It provides its clients not just with loans, but with training and insurance cover as well.

loans.use: To purchase rice seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Twanzane Fele Mbahana Group

texts.en: Fele M., a 45-year-old married mother of 15 children, all in school, has sold cassava flour and palm oil for over 20 years. She will use the loan to purchase more cassava flour and palm oil in order to expand the business. Fele is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to purchase a television set.

loans.use: To purchase cassava flour and palm oil to increase the size of the business.

loans.name: Twanzane Laveri Musolo Group

texts.en: Laveri M. has a retail shop which she has been operating for over three years. She is using this loan to purchase retail items such as sugar, flour, soap, salt, sweets, biscuits, etc. adding stock to her business. She is 22 years old and married with four children. Two of her children are in school. Laveri is a hardworking business lady and she is an example to her fellow women. Her dream is to purchase a motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, flour, soap, salt, sweets, biscuits, etc.

loans.name: Twanzane Masika Janate Group

texts.en:
M. Janate is 38 years old and married with nine children, and they are all in school. She deals in a beans and cassava flour business and she has been in her business for over twenty years.

Janate is using the loan to purchase beans and cassava flour to improve on her stock and to give satisfaction to her customers. She is a very hardworking businesswoman and very courageous as well. Her dream is to buy a car.

loans.use: To purchase beans and cassava flour to improve her stock

loans.name: Preciosa

texts.en: Preciosa S. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 61 years old, widowed, and has four adult children. Preciosa owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2008, Preciosa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Preciosa is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Mariafe

texts.en:
Mariafe C. is from the village of Dicoyong Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 39 years old and married to Rofino C., who is in the Philippine Army.

Mariafe started her business with a small amount of capital ten years ago. She decided to become a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative and Paglaum helped her business to have additional capital. She deeply wishes that her business will flourish and that they can taste a good life ahead.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her grocery store

loans.name: Mary-Ann

texts.en: Mary-ann C. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 27 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. Mary-ann owns and operates a food stall, selling poultry products commonly known as balot in the local community. A balot or balut is a fertilized duck (or chicken) egg with a nearly-developed embryo inside that is boiled and eaten in the shell. Mary-ann has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Mary-ann joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Mary-ann is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 7th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Meta

texts.en:
Meta G. is 38 years old, single, and lives at Maribojoc, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. The family lend a hand in farming, specifically in corn production which is their primary activity.

Meta G. has been a member of Paglaum MPC since April 2005. Now she is applying for Php 10,000.00 to buy farm fertilizers and pesticides. She has many plans for the future - to have a family, to build a simple house and be able to save money for the future.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticides for her corn

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Mrs. Gemma M. of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental, is 19 years old, married to a fisherman, and has one child. She has been a member of Paglaum MPC since July 2008 and is engaged in fishing.

Having completed her 2nd loan, she is requesting a new loan of Php 10,000 for the repair of their fishing boat. The increased profit will enable them to send their child to school and allow them to have a decent life.

loans.use: To repair their fishing boat

loans.name: Celerina

texts.en: Celerina A. is from the town of Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 61 years old, married, and has six adult children. Celerina owns and operates a coconut business, planting and harvesting coconuts for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over thirty years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Celerina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Celerina is requesting a new loan of 2,000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase her crop yield. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase her crop yield

loans.name: Tarciana

texts.en:
Mrs. Tarciana M. is 66 years old and married with no children. She is a pensioner and lives at Taboo, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental.

She joined Paglaum in May 2009 to secure financial assistance for house repair. The repayments will come from her monthly pension. She aspires to have a decent abode where she can spend the remaining days of her life.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Lilian J. is from the town of Misom, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 60 years old, married, and has seven adult children. Lilian owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2005, Lilian joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. Lilian is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Mrs. Gloria Q., is 43 years of age and a resident of Masabod, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is engaged in a fuel/gasoline retailing business from which she and her husband earn a living. Despite experiencing frequent and varied challenges, they are committed to meet those challenges rather than getting discouraged.

To feed and support their two children, Gloria and her husband work hard selling gasoline to the drivers in their community. They are now requesting a loan amounting to Php 5,000 to use as additional working capital. Gloria smiles at the thought of one day seeing her children receive their diplomas.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her fuel/gasoline business

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine R., a 53-year-old widow with three school-aged children, is from the city of Dipolog where she owns and operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products such as fish and shrimp to the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Josephine joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, Josephine is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used for the same purposes. This loan will be her eighth from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Mrs. Annabelle A., 32 years of age and a resident of Taboo, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental, has a fish-selling business from which she and her husband earn a living. Despite experiencing frequent and varied challenges, they are committed to meeting those challenges rather than getting discouraged.

To feed and support their five children, Annabelle and her husband work hard selling their catch at the market and sometimes wholesale buyers from nearby localities come to buy their catch. They are now requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP to acquire a fishing boat. Annabelle smiles at the thought of one day seeing her children receive their diplomas.

loans.use: To buy a fishing boat

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Mrs. Lolita B., a 55-year-old married mother of five children from Libertad Bajo, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental, began a business in food retailing to be of assistance in meeting the family’s daily basic needs and the children’s school allowances. Her regular customers are their friends, neighbors, and relatives. Lolita’s loan request of PHP 9,500.00, her twelfth, is intended as additional capital for her business.  She dreams of a comfortable living, having enough income to sustain their daily needs and for their old age.

loans.use: As additional capital for food retailing.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa M. owns and operates a specialized retail business selling electronic load in the local community. She is 45 years old, married and from the city of Dipolog. Teresa just started this business early this year.

In 2007, Teresa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Teresa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in a business selling homemade ice in the community. Teresa is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional working capital for e-load retailing. This will be her fourth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in e-load retail business

loans.name: Rosebel

texts.en: Rosebel S. is from the town of Katipunan. She is 32 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. Rosebel owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Rosebel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Rosebel is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase construction materials for house repair. This loan will be her 6th from PMPC. She plans to have a comfortable shelter for the family to live in. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for house repair

loans.name: Charlyn

texts.en: Charlyn M. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 26 years old, married, and has one infant child. Charlyn owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Charlyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Charlyn is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en: Teresa J. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 45 years old, married, and has two adult children. Teresa owns and operates a fishing business, primarily harvesting and selling wild-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Teresa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. Teresa is requesting a new loan of 5,500 PHP which will be used to build a new fishing boat. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To build a new fishing boat

loans.name: Pablita

texts.en:
A member who demonstrates excellent performance in terms of loan repayments, Mrs.Pablita M. is from Taboo, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old, married to a fisherman, and has eight children.

Pablita is currently engaged in a fish-vending business and manages her business well. She has obtained a loan amounting to Php 5,000 to acquire a fishing boat for her husband to operate. She aims to have a successful business with a concrete store and have the children finish a college degree and have a good future.

loans.use: To purchase fishing boat for her husband to operate

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen M. is from the town of Katipunan. She is 45 years old, married, and has four school-aged children.

Helen owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Helen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to pay for services to increase crop yield.

Alejandra has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Alejandra joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Alejandra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. She is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, to be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Alejandra from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

texts.en:
Mrs. Salud M. is 82 years old, widowed, with one child, a pensioner. She presently lives at Naga, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She joined Paglaum in June, 2009, to secure financial assistance for house completion, especially the wall finishing. She aspires to have a descent abode where she can spend the remaining days of her life.
The payment will be from her monthly pension. She is also glad to have access to the member’s mortuary assistance fund in the cooperative wherein she feels secure of her future resting.
